member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.HardwareInfo
member.summary: This structure is used by the method to return information about a Open Layers-compliant device collection.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.HardwareInfo.VendorId
member.summary: The identification number of the vendor. For most devices, this is 0x087 hexadecimal.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.HardwareInfo.CollectionId
member.summary: This field contains a unique collection ID value that is generated using the addition of the last two digits of the year multiplied by 10e7 (0 - 990000000) and the number of minutes into the current year (0 - 527040). Valid values for this field are 0 - 990527040;

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.HardwareInfo.NumberOfDevices
member.summary: This field contains the number of devices in the collection.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ChannelType
member.summary: Contains the possible values for the property.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ChannelType.SingleEnded
member.summary: Single-ended channel configuration. Use this configuration when you want to measure high-level signals, noise is insignificant, the source of the input is close to the device, and all the input signals are referred to the same common ground.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ChannelType.Differential
member.summary: Differential channel configuration. Use this configuration when you want to measure low-level signals (less than 1 V), you are using an A/D converter with high resolution (greater than 12 bits), noise is a significant part of the signal, or common-mode voltage exists.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.Encoding
member.summary: Contains the possible values for the SubsystemBase. and OlBuffer. properties, and for the Encoding parameter of the and methods.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.Encoding.Binary
member.summary: Binary data encoding

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.Encoding.TwosComplement
member.summary: Twos complement data encoding

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.TriggerType
member.summary: Contains the possible values for the , , and properties.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.TriggerType.Software
member.summary: Software (internal) trigger. The trigger occurs when the method is executed.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.TriggerType.TTLPos
member.summary: An external digital (TTL) signal attached to the device. The trigger occurs when the device detects a transition on the rising edge of the digital TTL signal.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.TriggerType.DigitalEvent
member.summary: A trigger is generated when an external digital event occurs.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.TriggerType.TTLNeg
member.summary: An external digital (TTL) signal attached to the device. The trigger occurs when the device detects a transition on the falling edge of the digital TTL signal.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.TriggerType.ThresholdPos
member.summary: Either an analog signal from an analog input channel or an external analog signal attached to the device. A positive analog threshold trigger occurs when the device detects a positive-going signal that crosses a threshold value. The threshold level is generally set using an analog output subsystem on the device.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.TriggerType.ThresholdNeg
member.summary: Either an analog signal from an analog input channel or an external analog signal attached to the device. A negative analog threshold trigger occurs when the device detects a negative-going signal that crosses a threshold value. The threshold level is generally set using an analog output subsystem on the device.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ClockSource
member.summary: Contains the possible values for the property.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ClockSource.Internal
member.summary: The internal clock is the clock source on the device that paces data acquisition or output for each channel in the ChannelList, or that is used in a counter/timer operation.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ClockSource.External
member.summary: An external clock source is an input signal attached to the device that paces data acquisition or output for each channel in the ChannelList, or that is used in a counter/timer operation. This clock source is useful when you want to operate at rates not available with the internal clock or if you want to operate at uneven intervals.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.DataFlow
member.summary: Contains the possible values for the property.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.DataFlow.Continuous
member.summary: Use continuous mode when you want to acquire or output data from multiple channels continuously. For analog input operations, this is post-trigger mode. For maximum flexibility, you can specify other parameters, such as the ChannelList, clock source and frequency, buffer, and so on.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.DataFlow.SingleValue
member.summary: In a single-value operation, a single data value is read from or written to a single channel immediately, and then the operation stops. You specify only the channel to read or update, and the gain for the channel.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.DataFlow.ContinuousPreTrigger
member.summary: Use continuous pre-trigger mode when you want to continuously acquire data before a specific external trigger event occurs. For maximum flexibility, you can specify other parameters, such as the ChannelList, clock source and frequency, buffer, and so on.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.DataFlow.ContinuousPrePostTrigger
member.summary: Use continuous about-trigger mode when you want to continuously acquire data both before and after a specific external event occurs. This operation is equivalent to doing both a pre-trigger and a post-trigger acquisition For maximum flexibility, you can specify other parameters, such as the ChannelList, clock source and frequency, buffer, and so on.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.WrapMode.None
member.summary: The operation continues indefinitely as long as you process the buffers and put them back on the queue in a timely manner.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.WrapMode.Single
member.summary: The first buffer is reused continuously. Some devices have a FIFO onboard for analog output (waveform generation) operations. If the buffer fits into the FIFO, the device driver downloads the buffer into the FIFO on the device. The driver (or device) outputs the data starting from the first location in the buffer. When it reaches the end of the buffer, the driver (or device) continues outputting data from the first location of the buffer, and the process continues indefinitely until you stop it.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.Stop
member.summary: Stops an operation on the subsystem after the current buffer has been filled for input operations or output for output operations.
member.remarks: This method is overridden in derived classes.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.Reset
member.summary: Stops a continuous operation on a subsystem immediately without waiting for the current buffer to be filled or output, and reinitializes the subsystem to the default configuration.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.Abort
member.summary: Stops an operation on the subsystem immediately.
member.remarks: This method is overridden in derived classes.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.Device
member.summary: Returns the object that is associated with the subsystem.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.Element
member.summary: Returns the element number of the subsystem.
member.remarks: Your device may support multiple instances, called elements, of the same subsystem type. Element numbering is zero-based; that is, the first instance of the subsystem is called element 0, the second instance of the subsystem is called element 1, and so on. For example, if your device has two digital input ports, two subsystems of type DigitalInput are available, differentiated as elements 0 and 1.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.State
member.summary: Returns the current state of the subsystem (Initialized, ConfiguredForSingleValue, ConfiguredForContinuous, PreStarted, Running, Stopping, Aborting, or IoComplete).

member.name: E:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.GeneralFailureEvent
member.summary: Occurs when a general library failure is encountered.

member.name: E:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.DeviceRemovedEvent
member.summary: Occurs when a device is removed from your system while your application is running.

member.name: E:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.QueueDoneEvent
member.summary: Occurs when no OlBuffer objects are available on the queue and the operation stops.

member.name: E:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.QueueStoppedEvent
member.summary: For analog input operations, occurs when a pre- or post-trigger acquisition operation completes or when you stop a continuous analog input operation. For analog output operations, occurs when a continuous analog output operation stops and the queue is emptied.

member.name: E:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.BufferDoneEvent
member.summary: For input operations, occurs when the OlBuffer object has been filled with post-trigger data. For output operations, occurs when all the data in the OlBuffer object has been output. If you stop an analog I/O operation, the event BufferDoneEvent is generated for the current buffer and for up to eight inprocess buffers before a QueueStoppedEvent event occurs.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.SubsystemType
member.summary: Returns the subsystem type (AnalogInput, AnalogOutput, DigitalInput, DigitalOutput, CounterTimer, or QuadratureDecoder).

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.StopOnError
member.summary: Gets or sets the stop-on-error condition (stop if overrun or underrun occurs, or continue if overrun or underrun occurs).
member.remarks: If StopOnError is True, the subsystem automatically stops when an overrun or underrun error occurs. If StopOnError is False, the subsystem continues to run when an overrun or underrun error occurs.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.AsynchronousStop
member.summary: Gets or sets the stop behavior (synchronous or asynchronous) of the subsystem.
member.remarks: If you set the AsynchronousStop property to True, control returns to your program after is called. If you set the AsynchronousStop property to False (the default setting), control does not return to your program after Stop is called until the object completes. (It is recommended that you do not wait more than 20 seconds for the stop to complete.) If you try to perform another operation while the stop is in progress, an exception is raised with the error code "SubsystemStopping" and the exception message "The subsystem is in the process of stopping or aborting".

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.ChannelType
member.summary: Gets and sets the (SingleEnded or Differential) for the subsystem.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.DataFlow
member.summary: Gets and sets the mode (Continuous, SingleValue, ContinuousPreTrigger, or ContinuousPrePostTrigger) of the subsystem.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.Encoding
member.summary: Gets and sets the data (Binary or TwosComplement) of the subsystem.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.Resolution
member.summary: Gets and sets the resolution of the subsystem.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.SynchronizationMode
member.summary: For subsystems that allow you to synchronize operations on multiple devices using a synchronization connector, gets and sets the synchronization mode (None, Master, or Slave).
member.remarks: If the synchronization mode is None, the subsystem is configured to ignore the synchronization circuit on the device. If the synchronization mode is Master, the synchronization connector on the device is configured to output a synchronization signal. If the synchronization mode is Slave, the synchronization connector on the device is configured to accept a synchronization signal as an input.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.SupportsSingleEnded

member.remarks: Use the property to set the channel configuration to SingleEnded.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.SupportsDifferential
member.summary: Returns True if the subsystem supports channels; otherwise, returns False.
member.remarks: Use the property to set the channel configuration to Differential.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.SupportsBinaryEncoding

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.MaxSingleEndedChannels

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.MaxDifferentialChannels

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.SupportsTwosCompEncoding

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.NumberOfChannels
member.summary: Returns the total number of channels that are supported by the subsystem.
member.remarks: This total number of channels includes both native and non-native channels that are supported for the subsystem. For example, if the analog input subsystem supports the ability to stream both analog and digital input data, the digital input channels will be included with the analog input channels in the total channel count. See also and .

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.SupportsSoftwareResolution
member.summary: Returns True if the subsystem supports software-programmable resolution; otherwise, returns False.
member.remarks: Use the property to specify the resolution for the subsystem.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.NumberOfResolutions
member.summary: Returns the number of resolutions that are supported by the subsystem.
member.remarks: To get an array of available resolutions that are supported by the subsystem, use the property. Use the property to specify the resolution for the subsystem.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.SupportedResolutions
member.summary: Returns an array of available resolutions that are supported by the subsystem.
member.remarks: Use the property to specify the resolution for the subsystem.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.FifoSize
member.summary: Returns the size of the FIFO on the device that is associated with the subsystem.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.SupportsWaveformModeOnly
member.summary: Returns True if the subsystem supports waveform-based operations using the onboard FIFO only; otherwise, returns False. If this property is True, the buffer wrap mode must be set to . In addition, the buffer size must be less than or equal to the .

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.ReturnsFloats
member.summary: Returns True if the subsystem returns data as floating-point values; otherwise, returns False indicating that the subsystem returns data as integer values.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemBase.SupportsCurrentOutput

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogSubsystem.VoltsToRawValue(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Converts a voltage value into a raw count.
member.param: The voltage value to convert.
The gain that was applied to input signal to produce the voltage.
member.returns: The raw count that is associated with the voltage value.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogSubsystem.RawValueToVolts(System.UInt16,System.Double)
member.summary: Converts a raw count into a voltage value.
member.param: The raw count to convert.
The gain to apply to the value. The gain is typically applied to the input signal at acquisition time.
member.returns: The voltage value that is associated with the raw count.
member.remarks: Use this method when the subsystem has a resolution of 16 bits or less.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogSubsystem.RawValueToVolts(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Converts a raw count into a voltage value.
member.param: The raw count to convert.
The gain to apply to the value. The gain is typically applied to the input signal at acquisition time.
member.returns: The voltage value that is associated with the raw count.
member.remarks: Use this method when the subsystem has a resolution of greater than 16 bits.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogSubsystem.RawValueToSensor(System.UInt16,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Converts a raw count to a sensor value in engineering units.
member.param: The raw count to convert.
The gain of the input signal, which is used to convert the raw count to a prescaled voltage value.
The sensor gain that is applied to the prescaled voltage value.
The sensor offset that is applied to the prescaled voltage value.
member.returns: The sensor value that is associated with the raw count.
member.remarks:
Use this method when the subsystem has a resolution of 16 bits or less.
The scaling occurs in two steps. First, the raw count is converted to a prescaled voltage by applying the gain for the input signal. Then, the prescaled voltage value is scaled using the equation y = mx + b, where y is the scaled sensor value, m is the sensor gain, x is the prescaled value in voltage, and b is the sensor offset.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogSubsystem.RawValueToSensor(System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Converts a raw count to a sensor value in engineering units.
member.param: The raw count to convert.
The gain of the input signal, which is used to convert the raw count to a prescaled voltage value.
The sensor gain that is applied to the prescaled voltage value.
The sensor offset that is applied to the prescaled voltage value.
member.returns: The sensor value that is associated with the raw count.
member.remarks:
Use this method when the subsystem has a resolution greater than 16 bits.
The scaling occurs in two steps. First, the raw count is converted to a prescaled voltage by applying the gain for the input signal. Then, the prescaled voltage value is scaled using the equation y = mx + b, where y is the scaled sensor value, m is the sensor gain, x is the prescaled value in voltage, and b is the sensor offset.

member.name: E:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogSubsystem.IOCompleteEvent
member.summary: Occurs when the last data point has been output from an analog output channel, or when the last sample has been copied to an analog input buffer on devices that support TTL and analog threshold stop trigger. In some cases, this event is raised well after the data is transferred from the buffer (and, therefore, well after BufferDoneEvent and QueueDoneEvents occur).

member.name: E:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogSubsystem.DriverRunTimeErrorEvent
member.summary: Occurs when the device driver detects one of the following error conditions during runtime: FifoOverflow, FifoUnderflow, DeviceOverClocked, TriggerError, or DeviceError. See for more information.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogSubsystem.QueuedBufferDones
member.summary: Returns the number of Buffer Done Events queued to be sent when is true.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogSubsystem.SynchronousBufferDone
member.summary: Gets or sets the way Buffer Done events are executed (asynchronously or synchronously). If False, each Buffer Done event is executed asynchronously in its own thread. If True, all Buffer Done events are executed synchronously from a single worker thread.
member.remarks: If your program is running under a heavy CPU load and this property is False, .NET may call your Buffer Done delegates out of order under certain circumstances. To avoid this problem, it is recommended that you set this property to True.

member.summary: Stops a continuous operation on the subsystem immediately without waiting for the current buffer to be filled.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogInputSubsystem.GetSingleValueAsVolts(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Acquires a single value from an analog input channel and returns the data in voltage.
member.param: The physical analog input channel to sample.
The gain to apply to the input signal.
member.returns: The acquired value in voltage.
member.remarks:
For subsystems that support thermocouples ( is True), a voltage value is returned only if the specified channel is configured for a of None. If the channel is configured for any other , an exception is raised.
If your device supports multiple sensor types for each channel ( is True), ensure that the channel is configured for VoltageIn using the property before calling this method.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogInputSubsystem.GetSingleValueAsSensor(System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Acquires a single value from an analog input channel and returns it in the engineering units of the specified sensor.
member.param: Physical analog input channel to sample.
Gain to apply to the input signal to get the prescaled voltage value.
Sensor gain value to apply to the prescaled voltage value. The default value is 1.
Sensor offset value to apply to the prescaled voltage value. The default value is 0.
member.returns: The scaled value in the engineering units of the sensor.
member.remarks:
If your device supports multiple sensor types for each channel ( is True), ensure that the channel is configured for VoltageIn using the property before calling this method.
The sensor gain and offset are used to scale a sample from raw counts to a sensor format. The scaling occurs in two steps. First, the raw count value is acquired and converted to prescaled voltage using the gain applied to the channel. Then, the sensor gain and sensor offset parameters are applied to the prescaled voltage value using the linear equation y = mx + b, where y is the sensor value, m is the sensor gain, x is the prescaled value in voltage, and b is the sensor offset.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogInputSubsystem.GetSingleValueAsRaw(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Acquires a single value from an analog input channel and returns it in raw counts.
member.param: Physical analog input channel to sample.
Gain to apply to the input signal.
member.returns: The analog input value in raw counts.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogInputSubsystem.GetSingleValuesAsVolts(System.Double)
member.summary: For subsystems that support simultaneous operations ( is True), simultaneously acquires a single value from each analog input channel and returns the data as an array of voltages based on each channel's .
member.remarks:
For subsystems that support thermocouples ( is True), any channel that is configured for a of None returns a voltage value and any channel that is configured for any other returns a temperature value.
If your device supports multiple sensor types for each channel ( is True), ensure that each channel is configured for VoltageIn using the property before calling this method.
member.param: Gain to apply to the input signal.
member.returns: An array of analog input values in voltage. Each index item of the array corresponds to a channel index in the collection for the analog input subsystem.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogInputSubsystem.GetSingleCjcValuesAsTemperature(OpenLayers.Base.TemperatureUnit)
member.summary: For subsystems that support simultaneous operations ( is True), supports thermocouples ( is True), and supports that ability to return data as floating-point values ( is True), acquires the CJC temperature for each input channel on the subsystem, and returns the CJC temperatures, in the units you specify, as floating-point values.
member.remarks: This function is seldom needed. It is provided in the rare case when you want to implement your own temperature conversion algorithms in software based on the CJC values. To use this function, the subsystem must be configured for a single value operation. Refer to your driver documentation for more information.
member.param: The of the CJC values that are returned.
member.returns: The CJC temperature of each input channel, in the units you specified. These temperatures are represented as floating-point (double) values.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogInputSubsystem.GetSingleValuesAsTemperature(OpenLayers.Base.TemperatureUnit)
member.summary: For subsystems that support simultaneous operations ( is True) and thermocouples ( is True), simultaneously acquires a single temperature value from each analog input channel and returns the data, in the units you specify, as an array of floating-point values based on each channel's .
member.param: The of the temperature values that are returned.
member.returns: The temperature value of each input channel, in the units you specified. The temperatures are represented as floating-point (double) values.
member.remarks: For subsystems that support thermocouples ( is True), any channel that is configured for a of None returns a voltage value and any channel that is configured for any other returns a temperature value.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogInputSubsystem.GetSingleCjcValueAsTemperature(System.Int32,OpenLayers.Base.TemperatureUnit)
member.summary: For subsystems that support thermocouples ( is True) and can return data as floating-point values ( is True), acquires the CJC temperature for the specified input channel, and returns the CJC temperature, in the units you specify, as a floating-point value.
member.remarks: This function is seldom needed. It is provided in the rare case when you want to implement your own temperature conversion algorithms in software based on the CJC temperature. To use this function, the subsystem must be configured for a single value operation.
member.param: The physical analog input channel to sample.
The of the CJC value that is returned.
member.returns: The CJC temperature of the specified input channel, in the units you specified. This temperature is represented as a floating-point (double) value.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogInputSubsystem.GetSingleValueAsTemperature(System.Int32,OpenLayers.Base.ThermocoupleType,OpenLayers.Base.TemperatureUnit)
member.summary: For subsystems that support thermocouples ( is True), acquires a single temperature value from an analog input channel using the specified thermocouple type and temperature unit, and returns the temperature as a floating-point value.
member.param: Physical analog input channel to sample.
The that is connected to the specified physical channel.
The for the specified thermocouple type.
member.returns: The temperature of the specified input channel, in the specified units, represented as a floating-point value.
member.remarks:
A temperature value is returned only if the specified channel is configured for a other than None. If the channel is configured for a of None, an exception is raised.
If your device supports multiple sensor types for each channel ( is True), ensure that the channel is configured for Thermocouple measurements using the property before calling this method.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogInputSubsystem.GetSingleValueAsTemperature(System.Int32,OpenLayers.Base.RTDType,OpenLayers.Base.SensorWiringConfiguration,System.Double,OpenLayers.Base.TemperatureUnit)
member.summary: For subsystems that support RTDs ( is True), acquires a single temperature value from an analog input channel using the specified RTD type, R0 coefficient, sensor wiring configuration, and temperature unit, and returns the temperature as a floating-point value.
member.param: Physical analog input channel to sample.
The that is connected to the specified physical channel.
The that was used to connect the RTD to the specified physical channel.
The nominal resistance () of the RTD at zero degrees C.
The for the specified RTD.
member.returns: The temperature of the specified input channel, in the specified units, represented as a floating-point value.
member.remarks:
If the value of the rtdType parameter is set to Custom, you must set the , , , and properties of the to supply the coefficients for the Callendar-Van Dusen transfer function. Otherwise, the values that were stored internally for the , , and properties are used, based on the value of the rtdType parameter.
If your device supports multiple sensor types for each channel ( is True), ensure that the channel is configured for Rtd measurements using the property before calling this method.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogInputSubsystem.GetSingleValueAsTemperature(System.Int32,OpenLayers.Base.SensorWiringConfiguration,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,OpenLayers.Base.TemperatureUnit)
member.summary: For subsystems that support thermistors ( is True), acquires a single temperature value from the specified analog input channel based on the specified wiring configuration, A, B, and C coefficients, and temperature unit, and returns the temperature as a floating-point value.
member.param: Physical analog input channel to sample.
The that is used to connect the thermistor to the specified physical channel.
The A coefficient that is used in the Steinhart-Hart transfer function for the thermistor.
The B coefficient that is used in the Steinhart-Hart transfer function for the thermistor.
The C coefficient that is used in the Steinhart-Hart transfer function for the thermistor.
The for the specified thermistor.
member.returns: The temperature of the specified input channel, in the specified units, represented as a floating-point value.
member.remarks: If your device supports multiple sensor types for each channel ( is True), ensure that the channel is configured for Thermistor measurements using the property before calling this method.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogInputSubsystem.GetSingleValueAsResistance(System.Int32)
member.summary: For subsystems that support resistance measurements ( is True), acquires a single resistance value from the specified analog input channel, and returns the resistance as a floating-point value, in ohms.
member.param: Physical analog input channel to sample.
member.returns: The resistance value of the specified input channel, in ohms, represented as a floating-point value.
member.remarks:
The resistance measurement depends on the excitation current setting. See your hardware manual for setting the current source and current value. If the hardware supports more than one current source, use propety to set the current source. If the hardware supports internal current Source, use to determine the available current values and set property to one of the available current values.
If your device supports multiple sensor types for each channel ( is True), ensure that the channel is configured for Resistance measurements using the property before calling this method.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogInputSubsystem.GetSingleValueAsCurrent(System.Int32)
member.summary: For subsystems that support current measurements ( is True), acquires a single current value from the specified analog input channel, and returns the current measurement as a floating-point value, in amperes.
member.param: Physical analog input channel to sample.
member.returns: The current value of the specified input channel, in amperes, represented as a floating-point value.
member.remarks:
When the channel is configured for a current measurement, a built-in resistor is switched in across the channel input terminals. Refer to the user's manual for your device to determine the value of the built-in resistor across the channel input terminals, and to determine the maximum current value that can be measured.
If your device supports multiple sensor types for each channel ( is True), ensure that the channel is configured for Current measurements using the property before calling this method.

member.summary: For subsystems that support simultaneous operations ( is True), simultaneously acquires a single value from each analog input channel and returns an array of values in the engineering units of the specified sensors.

Sensor gain value to apply to the prescaled voltage value.

The sensor gain and offset are used to scale a sample from raw counts to a sensor format. The scaling occurs in two steps. First, the raw count values are acquired and converted to prescaled voltages using the gain applied to the channels. Then, the sensor gain and sensor offset parameters are applied to the prescaled voltage values using the linear equation y = mx + b, where y is the sensor value, m is the sensor gain, x is the prescaled value in voltage, and b is the sensor offset.

member.summary: For subsystems that support simultaneous operations ( is True), simultaneously acquires a single value from each input channel and returns the data as an array of raw counts.
member.remarks: If your device supports streaming digital inputs, counter/timers, and/or quadrature decoder inputs through the analog input subsystem, this method returns the data for all the analog input channels, digital input ports, counter/timer channels, and/or quadrature decoder channels. For meaningful digital input, counter/timer, and/or quadrature decoder data, ensure that you configure and/or start an operation on these subsystems before calling GetSingleValuesAsRaw.
member.param: Gain to apply to the input signal.
member.returns: An array of data values in raw counts. Each index item of the array corresponds to a channel index in the collection for the analog input subsystem.

member.summary: Returns True if the subsystem supports channels that are used for cold junction compensation (CJC); otherwise, returns False.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogInputSubsystem.GetOneBuffer(OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Using continuous acquisition, acquires a buffer of data NumberOfSample long from the specified channel. This method uses the current clock frequency, trigger, etc., for the acquisition. This method is synchronous and returns only after the requested data has been acquired or a calculated timeout value has been exceeded.
member.param: object, which represents the channel from which to acquire data.
Number of samples to acquire
Timeout value, in milliseconds, to wait for buffer completion. A value of -1 means the timeout is infinite.
member.returns: An object with the specified number of samples.
member.remarks: This method allocates a buffer and starts the continuous analog input operation automatically using the current configuration of the analog input subsystem. This method is synchronous and returns only after the requested data has been acquired or the specified timeout value, in milliseconds, has been exceeded. No BufferDoneEvents occur. If the buffer is not filled before the specified timeout value is exceeded, AnalogInputSubsystem.Abort is called and a TimeoutException is raised. If a GeneralFailureEvent or DriverRuntimeErrorEvent occurs during acquisition, an OlException with the appropriate error code is raised. Once the buffer is returned, you can copy the data from the buffer into an array using the OlBuffer methods.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.AnalogInputSubsystem.ReturnCjcTemperaturesInStream
member.summary: Enables or disables the subsystem from returning CJC values in the data stream.
member.remarks:
This function is seldom needed. It is provided only for analog input subsystems that support the capability of converting temperature data (based on CJC values) in hardware.
If you disable the subsystem from returning CJC values in the data stream (ReturnCjcTemperaturesInStream is False; the default state), the subsystem returns a corrected and linearized value for each input channel. Every sample in the data stream corresponds to a single (typically, floating-point) value that represents either the temperature (in degrees C) or the voltage of the input channel, based on its . No CJC values are returned in the data stream.
If you enable the subsystem to return CJC values in the data stream (ReturnCjcTemperaturesInStream is True), the subsystem returns both an input value and CJC value for each channel; you can then implement your own temperature conversion algorithms in software to convert the data as desired. Two (typically floating-point) values are returned in the data stream for each channel: the first value represents the temperature or voltage of the input channel (based on the of the input), and the second value represents the CJC temperature, in degrees C. Generally, in this configuration, a thermocouple type of None is specified for each channel. If you return CJC values in the data stream, ensure that you allocate a buffer that is twice as large to accommodate the CJC values (number of samples x 2).
To use this function, the subsystem must be configured for a continuous operation using the property. This feature is supported only if the subsystem supports thermocouples (see ) and the subsystem supports interleaved CJC values in the data stream (see ).

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer
member.summary: The OlBuffer class encapsulates a data buffer that is used in a continuous I/O operation.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.#ctor(System.Int32,OpenLayers.Base.AnalogSubsystem)
member.summary: Creates and returns an OlBuffer object, and allocates an internal data buffer that will contain a specified number of samples.
member.param: Maximum number of samples that the internal buffer can contain. This parameter determines the size of the internal buffer. Note that if you use the property to return CJC data in the data stream, ensure that you set the size of the internal buffer to be twice as large to accommodate the returned CJC values for each channel (iNumSamples = number of samples per channel x 2).
The subsystem (AnalogInputSubsystem or AnalogOutputSubsystem) with which the OlBuffer object is initially associated.
member.remarks:
The values for voltage range, channel list, data encoding, and resolution that are applied to the OlBuffer object are determined by the subsystem with which it is associated. Initially (and by default), these values are determined by the subsystem that is specified in the constructor above.
If, however, you later use the OlBuffer object with a different subsystem type, these values are determined by subsystem with which it is used. For example, if the OlBuffer object was initially associated with an analog output subsystem, and then put on an analog input subsystem queue, the values for voltage range, channel list, data encoding, and resolution will be updated to reflect the settings of the analog input subsystem when the OlBuffer object is completed by the device driver.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.Finalize
member.summary: Object Finalize method.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.Reallocate(System.Int32)
member.summary: Reallocates the internal data buffer of the OlBuffer object to contain the specified number of samples. The existing internal data buffer is deallocated and any data that it contained is lost.
member.param: Maximum number of samples that the internal data buffer can contain. This parameter determines the size of the internal buffer. Note that if you use the property to return CJC data in the data stream, ensure that you set the size of the internal buffer to be twice as large to accommodate the returned CJC values for each channel (iNumSamples = number of samples per channel x 2).
member.returns: True if allocation was successful; otherwise, returns False.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.GetDataAsResistance(OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry)
member.summary: For a specified ChannelListEntry, converts the data from the internal buffer of an OlBuffer object into resistance values, and then copies these resistance values into a user-declared array of 64-bit floating-point (double) values.
member.param: object, which represents the channel whose data you want to convert and copy.
member.returns: An array of resistance values, represented as 64-bit floating-point (double) values, that are associated with a specified ChannelListEntry.
member.remarks: Note that if the ChannelListEntry occurs more than once in the buffer, the data for each occurrence of the ChannelListEntry is copied. This method raises an exception if the property for the channel is not Resistance.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.GetDataAsTemperatureDouble(OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry,OpenLayers.Base.TemperatureUnit)
member.summary: For a specified ChannelListEntry, converts the data from the internal buffer of an OlBuffer object into temperature values, and then copies these temperature values into a user-declared array of 64-bit floating-point (double) values.
member.param: object, which represents the channel whose data you want to convert and copy.
The units (Celsius, Fahrenheit, or Kelvin) for the temperature values.
member.returns: An array of temperature values that are associated with a specified ChannelListEntry, represented as 64-bit floating-point values (double).
member.remarks:
This method converts only the data associated with a specified ChannelListEntry in the buffer into temperature values, and then copies this data into a user-declared array of 64-bit floating-point values (double).
For thermocouple channels, the data is converted into temperature based on the channel's property.
For RTD channels, the data is converted into temperature based on the channel's , , , , and properties.
For thermistor channels, the data is converted into temperature based on the channel's , , and properties.
Note that if the ChannelListEntry occurs more than once in the buffer, the data for each occurrence of the ChannelListEntry is converted and copied.
If is True, this method raises an exception if the is set to None. If is set to True, the CJC values (in temperature) are interleaved with the channel data, where the first value represents the temperature of the input channel and the second value represents the CJC temperature, in degrees C; the returned array will be twice the number of valid samples ().

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.GetDataAsTemperatureByte(OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry,OpenLayers.Base.TemperatureUnit,System.Int32)
member.summary: For a specified ChannelListEntry, converts the data from the internal buffer of an OlBuffer object into temperature values, and then copies these temperature values into a user-declared array of bytes. Each temperature value is stored as an Int32, and takes 4 bytes.
member.param: object, which represents the channel whose data you want to convert and copy.
The units (Celsius, Fahrenheit, or Kelvin) for the temperature values.
The amount by which to scale each temperature value. By default, this is 1.
member.returns: An array of temperature values that is associated with a specified ChannelListEntry, represented as bytes.
member.remarks:
This method converts only the data associated with a specified ChannelListEntry in the buffer into temperature values, and then copies this data into a user-declared array of bytes.
For thermocouple channels, the data is converted into temperature based on the channel's property.
For RTD channels, the data is converted into temperature based on the channel's , , , , and properties.
For thermistor channels, the data is converted into temperature based on the channel's , , and properties.
Note that if the ChannelListEntry occurs more than once in the buffer, the data for each occurrence of the ChannelListEntry is converted and copied.
If is True, this method raises an exception if the is set to None. If is set to True, the CJC values (in temperature) are interleaved with the channel data, where the first value represents the temperature of the input channel and the second value represents the CJC temperature, in degrees C; the returned array will be twice the number of valid samples ().

member.remarks: Used when the resolution of the subsystem is 16 bits or less, copies only the raw count values for a specified ChannelListEntry from a user-specified array into the internal buffer of an OlBuffer object.
member.param: object, which represents the channel whose data you want to copy.
The user-specified array containing the channel data, in raw counts, to copy. This data is represented as unsigned 16-bit integers (ushort).

remarks.para: Note that if the ChannelListEntry occurs more than once in the array, the data for each occurrence of the ChannelListEntry is copied.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.PutDataAsRaw(OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry,System.UInt32[])
member.summary: Copies raw counts from a user-specified array into the internal buffer of an OlBuffer object.
member.remarks: Used when the resolution of the subsystem is greater than 16 bits, copies only the raw count values for a specified ChannelListEntry from a user-specified array into the internal buffer of an OlBuffer object.
member.param: object, which represents the channel whose data you want to copy.
The user-specified array containing the channel data, in raw counts, to copy. This data is represented as unsigned 32-bit integers (uint).

remarks.para: Note that if the ChannelListEntry occurs more than once in the array, the data for each occurrence of the ChannelListEntry is copied.

member.remarks: This method copies all the voltage values from a user-specified array into the internal buffer of an OlBuffer object.
member.param: The user-specified array containing the voltage values to copy. The data is represented as 64-bit floating-point values (double).

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.GetDataAsSensor(OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry)
member.summary: This method converts only the data for a specified ChannelListEntry in the internal buffer of an OlBuffer object into sensor values (using the and ), and then copies these sensor values into a user-declared array of 64-bit floating-point values (double).
member.param: , which represents the channel whose data you want to copy.
member.returns: A user-declared array of sensor values associated with all the samples for a given ChannelListEntry, represented as 64-bit floating-point values (double).
member.remarks: This method converts only the data associated with a specified ChannelListEntry in the internal buffer of an OlBuffer object into sensor values, then copies this data into a user-declared array of 64-bit floating-point values (double). Note that if the ChannelListEntry occurs more than once in the buffer, the data for each occurrence of the ChannelListEntry is copied.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.GetDataAsSensor(OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: This method converts a range of samples for each occurrence of ChannelListEntry in the internal buffer of an OlBuffer object into sensor values (using the and ), and then copies these sensor values into a user-declared array of 64-bit floating-point values (double). It allocates and returns an array size equal to the number of valid samples. The samples that are outside of the requested range are 0.0.
member.param: object, which represents the channel whose data you want to copy.
The first sample in the OlBuffer object that you want to convert and copy; this number is zero-based.
The last sample in the range that you want to convert and copy; this number is inclusive.
member.returns: A user-declared array of sensor values associated with a range of samples for a given ChannelListEntry, represented as 64-bit floating-point values (double).

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.GetDataAsSensor
member.summary: Converts the data from the internal buffer of an OlBuffer object into sensor values (using the and ), and then copies these sensor values into a user-declared array of 64-bit floating-point values (double).
member.returns: A user-specified array of sensor values, represented as 64-bit floating-point values (double).
member.remarks: This method copies all the samples from the buffer into a user-declared array of 64-bit floating-point values (double).

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.GetDataAsVolts(OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry)
member.summary: For a specific channel, converts the data from the internal buffer of an OlBuffer object into voltage values, and then copies these voltage values into a user-declared array of 64-bit floating-point values (double).
member.param: object, which represents the channel whose data you want to copy.
member.returns: An array of voltages that are associated with a specified ChannelListEntry, represented as 64-bit floating-point values (double).
member.remarks:
This method converts only the data associated with a specified ChannelListEntry in the buffer into voltage values, and then copies this data into a user-declared array of 64-bit floating-point values (double). Note that if the ChannelListEntry occurs more than once in the buffer, the data for each occurrence of the ChannelListEntry is copied.
For thermocouple channels ( property is Thermocouple), the property is typically set to None before using this method. However, if the property is set to a value other than None, this method returns the value of the channel in temperature. Additionally, if is set to True, the CJC values (in temperature) are interleaved with the channel data, where the first value represents the temperature or voltage of the input channel (based on the ), and the second value represents the CJC temperature, in degrees C; the returned array will be twice the number of valid samples ().

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.GetDataAsVolts(OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts a range of samples for a specified channel in the internal buffer of an OlBuffer object into voltage values, and then copies these voltage values into a user-specified array. This method converts and copies one sample for each occurrence of channelNum in the . This version of the method allocates and returns an array size equal to the number of valid samples. The samples that are outside of the requested range are 0.0.
member.param: object, which represents the channel whose data you want to copy.
The first sample in the internal buffer of the OlBuffer object that you want to convert and copy; this number is zero-based.
The last sample in the range that you want to convert and copy; this number is inclusive.
member.returns: A user-specified array of voltage values, which represent a range of samples for a given channel.
member.remarks: For thermocouple channels ( is Thermocouple), the property is typically set to None before using this method. However, if the property is set to a value other than None, this method returns the values of the channels in temperature. Additionally, if is set to True, the CJC values (in temperature) are interleaved with the channel data, where the first value represents the temperature or voltage of the input channel (based on the ), and the second value represents the CJC temperature, in degrees C; the returned array will be twice the number of valid samples ().

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.GetDataAsVolts
member.summary: Converts the data from the internal buffer of an OlBuffer object into voltage values, and then copies these voltage values into a user-declared array of 64-bit floating-point values (double).
member.returns: Returns a user-specified array of voltage values, represented as 64-bit floating-point values (double).
member.remarks:
This method copies all the data, as voltages, from the internal buffer of an OlBuffer object into a user-declared array of 64-bit floating-point values (double).
For thermocouple channels ( is Thermocouple), the property is typically set to None before using this method. However, if the property is set to a value other than None, this method returns the values of the channels in temperature. Additionally, if is set to True, the CJC values (in temperature) are interleaved with the channel data, where the first value represents the temperature or voltage of the input channel (based on the ), and the second value represents the CJC temperature, in degrees C; the returned array will be twice the number of valid samples ().

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.SampleSizeInBytes
member.summary: Returns the size, in bytes, of the samples in the internal buffer of the OlBuffer object.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.ValidSamples
member.summary: Returns the number of valid samples in the internal buffer of the OlBuffer object.
member.remarks:
For analog input operations, the ValidSamples property is set to the number of samples in the completed buffer under normal circumstances. However, in some cases, like if is called in the middle of an operation, ValidSamples reflects the number of samples in the buffer when Abort was called. In addition, if Abort or is called, any OlBuffer objects whose state is Inprocess will have a ValidSamples of 0.
If your device supports thermocouples ( is True), and is set to True, CJC values (in temperature) are interleaved with the channel data in the buffer, where the first value represents the temperature or voltage of the input channel (based on the ), and the second value represents the CJC temperature, in degrees C. In this case, the returned array will be twice the number of valid samples ().
For analog output operations, ValidSamples is always equal to the maximum number of samples that the buffer was allocated to hold. If you are using thermocouples and is set to True, CJC values will be interleaved with the channel data; therefore, the returned array will be twice the number of valid samples.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.BufferState.Queued
member.summary: The OlBuffer object has been queued to a subsystem.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.BufferState.InProcess
member.summary: The OlBuffer object has been sent to the device driver for processing. A maximum of eight OlBuffer objects can be in process at one time.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.BufferState.Completed
member.summary: For an input operation, the internal buffer of the OlBuffer object has been filled with data, and has not been put back on the queue for the subsystem. For an output operation, all the data in the internal buffer of the OlBuffer object has been output, and the OlBuffer object has not been put back on the queue for the subsystem.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer.BufferState.Released
member.summary: The internal buffer of the OlBuffer object has been deallocated.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.BufferQueue
member.summary: The BufferQueue class provides an interface for queuing objects to a device's subsystem for continuous I/O operations.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.BufferQueue.QueueBuffer(OpenLayers.Base.OlBuffer)
member.summary: Adds an object to the subsystem queue.
member.remarks: If the subsystem is incompatible with the specified object, an exception is raised.
member.param: The object to add to the subsystem queue.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.BufferQueue.DequeueBuffer
member.summary: Removes the object from the front of the subsystem queue, and returns it to the user.
member.returns: The object from the front of the queue.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.BufferQueue.FreeAllQueuedBuffers
member.summary: Removes all objects from the subsystem queue and deallocates the associated internal buffer.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.BufferQueue.QueuedCount
member.summary: Returns the number of objects that are on the subsystem queue (OlBuffer objects are in the queued state).
member.remarks: When you start a continuous operation, the device takes up to eight OlBuffer objects from the subsystem queue and begins filling the associated internal buffers (for input operations) or outputting data from the associated internal buffers (for output operations) at the specified clock rate. The state of these OlBuffer objects changes from queued to inprocess. Every time an OlBuffer object transitions from the queued state to the inprocess state, the value of the QueuedCount property decreases by one and the value of the InProcessCount property increases by 1. For example, assume that you call QueueBuffer for 10 OlBuffer objects; the QueuedCount is now 10 and the InProcessCount is 0. Once you call Start, up to 8 OlBuffer objects are moved from the queued state to the inprocess state. The QueuedCount is now 2 and the InProcessCount is now 8. As each OlBuffer object is completed, an event is generated allowing you to process the buffer. Assume that you do not put the OlBuffer objects back on the queue after processing them. In this case, the QueuedCount decreases while the InProcessCount remains the same (as a new inprocess OlBuffer object replaces a completed OlBuffer object) until the QueuedCount gets to 0, then the InProcessCount starts decreasing until all the OlBuffer objects are completed.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.BufferQueue.InProcessCount
member.summary: Returns the number of objects that have been taken from subsystem queue and sent to the device for processing (buffers are in the inprocess state).
member.remarks: When you start a continuous operation, the device takes up to eight OlBuffer objects from the subsystem queue and begins filling the associated internal buffers (for input operations) or outputting data from the associated internal buffers for output operations) at the specified clock rate. The state of these OlBuffer objects changes from queued to inprocess. Every time an OlBuffer object transitions from the queued state to the inprocess state, the value of the QueuedCount property decreases by one and the value of the InProcessCount property increases by 1. For example, assume that you call QueueBuffer for 10 OlBuffer objects; the QueuedCount is now 10 and the InProcessCount is 0. Once you call Start, up to 8 OlBuffer objects are moved from the queued state to the inprocess state. The QueuedCount is now 2 and the InProcessCount is now 8. As each OlBuffer object is completed, an event is generated allowing you to process the buffer. Assume that you do not put the OlBuffer objects back on the queue after processing them. In this case, the QueuedCount decreases while the InProcessCount remains the same (as a new inprocess OlBuffer object replaces a completed OlBuffer object) until the QueuedCount gets to 0, then the InProcessCount starts decreasing until all the OlBuffer objects are completed.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.ChannelList
member.summary: A ChannelList specifies a collection of objects for use in a continuous I/O operation. Each ChannelListEntry object encapsulates a physical channel connection for a specific subsystem.
member.remarks: A ChannelList is typically used in continuous analog input and analog output operations. You can add and/or insert a channel to the ChannelList by physical channel number, by name, or as a ChannelListEntry object.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.ChannelList.Add(System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds a channel to the end of the ChannelList.
member.param: The number of the physical channel on the specified subsystem to add to the ChannelList.
member.returns: A object for the physical channel that was added. You can then access this ChannelListEntry object through the ChannelList for the subsystem.
member.remarks:
Adds a channel, specified as a physical channel number, to the end of the ChannelList and returns a object for the channel.
This method provides a simple way to add channels into the ChannelList, particularly if you are adding channels that are native to the subsystem type (such as analog input channels on an analog input subsystem). For native channels, the physical channel number always equals the logical channel number. While non-native channels, such as digital inputs that are streamed through the analog input subsystem, can also be added this way, the physical channel number is not the same as the logical channel number, so you may find it easier to add a channel by name or by object instead.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.ChannelList.Insert(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Inserts a channel at the specified index of the ChannelList.
member.param: Zero-based index of the ChannelList at which to insert the object.
The physical channel number of the specified subsystem to add to the ChannelList.
member.returns: A object for the physical channel that was inserted. You can then access this ChannelListEntry object through the ChannelList for the subsystem.
member.remarks:
Inserts a channel, specified as a physical channel number, at the specified index of the ChannelList and returns a object for the channel.
This method provides a simple way to insert channels into the ChannelList, particularly if you are inserting channels that are native to the subsystem type (such as analog input channels on an analog input subsystem). For native channels, the physical channel number always equals the logical channel number. While non-native channels, such as digital inputs that are streamed through the analog input subsystem, can also be inserted this way, the physical channel number is not the same as the logical channel number, so you may find it easier to insert a channel by name or by object instead.
