member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannels
member.summary: The SupportedChannels class describes, through a collection of objects, the channels available for a particular subsystem.
member.remarks: It is often the case that a subsystem of one type is capable of including data in its data stream from a different subsystem type. For example, an analog input subsystem, which has its own native analog input channels, may also stream data from non-native channels, such as a digital input port or counter/timer channel. Typically, these non-native channels are described in a channel list with numbers beyond the range of its native channels. The Open Layers for .NET Class Library allows you to deal with non-native channels more easily by describing channels in terms of subsystem type and logical channel numbers or channel names.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannels.GetChannelInfo(OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemType,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a SupportedChannelInfo object for the specified subsystem type and logical channel number.
member.remarks: If the channel has multiple logical channel words, this method returns the SupportedChannelInfo object for logical channel word 0.
member.param: Subsystem type.
Logical channel number for the subsystem type.
member.returns: SupportedChannelInfo object associated with the specified channel.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannels.GetChannelInfo(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the SupportedChannelInfo object for the specified channel name.
member.remarks: If the channel has multiple logical channel words, this method returns the SupportedChannelInfo object for logical channel word 0.
member.param: Channel name
member.returns: SupportedChannelInfo object associated with the specified channel.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannels.GetChannelInfo(OpenLayers.Base.SubsystemType,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the SupportedChannelInfo object for the specified subsystem type, logical channel, and logical channel word.
member.remarks: For channels like 32-bit counter/timers that return multi-word data, the logical channel word, which is zero-based, maps the physical channel to the data word that it returns. For example, a logical channel word of 0 indicates that this channel returns the first 16-bits of data. A logical channel word of 1 indicates that this channel returns the second 16-bits of data. For channels that do not return multi-word data, the value of the logical channel word is -1.
member.param: Subsystem type.
Logical channel number for the subsystem type.
Logical channel word for the specified logical channel number.
member.returns: SupportedChannelInfo object associated with the logical channel word.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannels.GetChannelInfo(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the SupportedChannelInfo object for the specified physical channel number.
member.remarks: If the channel has multiple logical channel words, this method returns the SupportedChannelInfo object for logical channel word 0.
member.param: Physical channel number of the subsystem.
member.returns: SupportedChannelInfo object associated with the specified channel.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannels.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the object at the specified index ([index]) of the object.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannels.Count
member.summary: Returns the number of objects in the SupportedChannels collection.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo
member.summary: The SupportedChannelInfo class describes a specific channel of a subsystem. You access a SupportedChannelInfo object using the class.
member.remarks: When you get a subsystem of a specified type, the software automatically determines the number of available channels for the subsystem and creates a SupportedChannelInfo object for each channel, containing the following information: physical channel number, logical channel number, logical channel word, channel name, sensor gain, and sensor offset.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.RTDType
member.summary: Gets and sets the for the RTD that is connected to the channel. This property is used in the Callendar-Van Dusen transfer function to convert raw counts to temperature.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.ThermocoupleType
member.summary: Gets and sets the that is connected to this channel.
member.remarks: By default, a J thermocouple type is used. The thermocouple type is used to convert a sample from raw counts to a temperature value in Celsius, Fahrenheit, or Kelvin. The software supplies the appropriate linearization algorithm based on the specified thermocouple type. To get the range for a specified thermocouple type, use the method.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.CjcChannel
member.summary: Gets the CJC (cold junction compensation) channel that is associated with this input channel.
member.remarks: This property applies only to devices that support a channel (not an internal source) as the CJC source.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.SensorGain
member.summary: Gets and sets the gain value to apply to the sensor that is connected to this channel.
member.remarks: By default, the sensor gain is 1. The sensor gain and offset are used to scale a sample from raw counts to a value in the engineering units of the sensor. The scaling occurs in two steps. First, the raw count value is converted to prescaled voltage using the gain applied to the input signal. Then, the prescaled voltage is scaled using the following equation: y = mx + b, where y is the scaled sensor value, m is the sensor gain, x is the prescaled value in voltage, and b is the sensor offset.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.SensorOffset
member.summary: Gets and sets the offset value to apply to the sensor that is connected to this channel.
member.remarks: By default, the sensor offset is 0. The sensor gain and offset are used to scale a sample from raw counts to a value in the engineering units of the sensor. The scaling occurs in two steps. First, the raw count value is converted to prescaled voltage using the gain applied to the input signal. Then, the prescaled voltage is scaled using the following equation: y = mx + b, where y is the scaled sensor value, m is the sensor gain, x is the prescaled value in voltage, and b is the sensor offset.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.Name
member.summary: Gets and sets the name of the associated channel.
member.remarks: Each SupportedChannelInfo object in a SupportedChannels collection object must have a unique name. By default, the channels have the following names, which you can modify, if you wish: For analog input channels, the channels are named Ain0, Ain1, and so on. For analog output channels, the channels are named Aout0, Aout1, and so on. For digital input channels, the channels are named Din0, Din1, and so on. For counter/timer channels, the channels are named CT0 Word 0, CT0 Word 1, CT1 Word 0, CT1 Word 1, and so on. For quadrature decoder channels, the channels are named Quad0 Word 0, Quad0 Word 1, Quad1 Word 0, Quad1 Word 1, and so on.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.SubsystemType
member.summary: Returns the type of subsystem (AnalogInput, AnalogOutput, DigitalInput, DigitalOutput, CounterTimer, or QuadratureDecoder) that is associated with this channel.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.LogicalChannelNumber
member.summary: Returns the zero-based logical channel number that is associated with this channel.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.LogicalChannelWord
member.summary: For channels with multi-word data (such as a 32-bit counter), returns the zero-based word number that is associated with this channel. For channels without multi-word data, returns -1.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.PhysicalChannelNumber
member.summary: Returns the physical channel number that is associated with this channel.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.Subsystem
member.summary: Returns the subsystem object (, , , , , , or ) that is associated with this channel.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.Coupling
member.summary: Gets and sets the to apply to the channel.
member.remarks: By default, DC coupling is selected for all channels.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.ExcitationCurrentSource
member.summary: Gets and sets the to apply to the channel.
member.remarks: By default, the excitation current source is disabled for all channels.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.ExcitationCurrentValue
member.summary: Gets and sets the value of the excitation current source to apply to the channel.
member.remarks: This value is applicable only when the excitation current source is internal.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.LogicalSsBaseClockFrequency
member.summary: Returns the frequency of the base clock for the logical subsystem.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.StrainGageOffsetNullingValueInVolts
member.summary: Gets and sets the value of the bridge output (in volts) in the unstrained/unloaded condition. Internally, this value is subtracted from any measurements before the voltage is converted to strain.
member.remarks: A balanced bridge under ideal conditions with zero strain applied produces zero volts. In practice, however, the output of a bridge in an unstrained condition is offset from zero slightly due to imperfect matching of bridge resistances. To perform offset nulling, read the value of the bridge in an unstrained condition using the AnalogInputSubsystem.GetSingleValueAsVolts method, and then specify the value that you read using this property. All subsequent data is then offset by this reference value.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.StrainGageShuntCalibrationValue
member.summary: Gets and sets the shunt calibration value, in microstrain, for the bridge. Internally, the software multiplies the channel measurement with this value to adjust the gain of the device.
member.remarks:
For an analog input channel that supports a strain gage input and shunt calibration, you can use shunt calibration to correct span errors in the measurement path. You can also use shunt calibration to verify the integrity of the setup by turning on the shunt resistor before you acquire data.
If you want to use the internal shunt calibration resistor provided by the device, ensure that the internal RSHUNT+ and RSHUNTâ€“ lines are connected across the gage and that no strain is applied to the specimen, and then enable the resistor by setting the property to True. (Be sure to set this value back to False when the shunt calibration procedure is complete.)
Once the shunt resistor is enabled, read the value of the bridge using the AnalogInputSubsystem.GetSingleValueAsStrain method. Then, divide the expected value of the bridge by the actual value that you read, and specify the result, in microstrain, using this property.
Refer to the user's manual for your device for more information on shunt calibration.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.StrainGageBridgeConfiguration
member.summary: Gets and sets the of the strain gage that is connected to the channel.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.BridgeConfiguration
member.summary: Gets and sets the of the full-bridge-based sensor or general-purpose bridge that is connected to the channel.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.StrainGageLeadWireResistance
member.summary: Gets and sets the lead wire resistance of the strain gage or bridge, in ohms.
member.remarks: If remote sensing is used, specify 0 for this property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.StrainGageGageFactor
member.summary: Gets and sets the gage factor, or sensitivity, of the strain gage.
member.remarks: This value is supplied by the manufacturer of the stain gage. Refer to the documentation for your strain gage for more information.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.StrainGageNominalResistance
member.summary: Gets and sets the resistance, in ohms, of the strain gage or bridge while it is not under strain/load.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.StrainGagePoissonRatio
member.summary: Gets and sets the Poisson ratio for the strain gage.
member.remarks: The Poisson ratio is a material-dependent constant that is the ratio of transverse (perpendicular) contraction to axial strain. Specify the Poisson ratio when the analog input channel is configured for one of the following strain gage configurations: FullBridgeBendingPoisson, FullBridgeAxialPoisson, or HalfBridgePoisson.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.StrainGageShuntCalibrationResistorEnabled
member.summary: Specifies whether the internal shunt calibration resistor is enabled (switched in) or disabled (not used).

remarks.para: If you want to use the internal shunt calibration resistor provided by the device, ensure that the internal RSHUNT+ and RSHUNTâ€“ lines are connected across the gage and that no strain is applied to the specimen, and then enable the resistor by setting this property to True. (Be sure to set this value back to False when the shunt calibration procedure is complete.)

Once the shunt resistor is enabled, read the value of the strain gage or bridge using the AnalogInputSubsystem.GetSingleValueAsStrain method. Then, divide the expected value of the strain gage or bridge by the actual value that you read, and specify the result, in microstrain, using the property.
Refer to the user's manual for your device for more information on shunt calibration.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.SupportsInputTermination
member.summary: Specifies whether input termination is supported for the analog input channel.
member.remarks: If input termination is supported for the channel, you can enable or disable the bias return termination resistor using the property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.InputTerminationEnabled
member.summary: Specifies whether input termination is enabled (bias return termination resistor is switched in) or disabled (not used) for the analog input channel.
member.remarks: This property is used only if the property is True. Refer to the hardware documentation for your device to determine when the bias return termination resistor should be enabled and disabled. Typically, the bias return termination resistor should be enabled for floating and grounded voltage and current sources, and disabled for voltage and current sources that have a grounded reference.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.TransducerRatedOutputInMv
member.summary: Gets and sets the rated output of a bridge-based sensor or transducer, such as a load cell, in terms of mV/V excitation.
member.remarks: This value is supplied by the manufacturer of the bridge-based sensor or transducer. The bridge-based sensor or transducer is based on the full-bridge configuration.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.TransducerCapacity
member.summary: Gets and sets the full-scale range of the bridge-based sensor or transducer, such as a load cell, in its native engineering units.
member.remarks: This value is supplied by the manufacturer of the bridge-based sensor or transducer. The bridge-based sensor or transducer is based on the full-bridge configuration.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.IOType
member.summary: Gets the measurement that is supported by the channel.
member.remarks: Some devices, such as the DT9829, support multiple sensor inputs for each channel and return a value of MultiSensor for the IOType property. If the channel has an IOType of MultiSensor, set the sensor type for the channel using the property. Most devices support only one IOType for each channel; setting the property is not applicable in this case.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.MultiSensorType
member.summary: If the property for the channel is MultiSensor, gets and sets the type of measurement that is supported by the channel.
member.remarks: Some devices, such as the DT9829, support multiple sensor inputs for each channel and return a value of MultiSensor for the property. If the channel has an of MultiSensor, set the sensor type for the channel using the MultiSensor property. Most devices support only one for each channel; setting the MultiSensorType property is not applicable in this case.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.StrainGageTeds
member.summary: Provides an interface to a object.
member.remarks: Use this interface to read TEDS data directly from the strain gage hardware or from a data file for a strain gage (virtual TEDS).

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.BridgeSensorTeds
member.summary: Provides an interface to a object.
member.remarks: Use this interface to read TEDS data directly from the bridge-based sensor hardware, such as a load cell, or from a data file for a bridge-based sensor (virtual TEDS).

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.SupportedMultiSensorTypes
member.summary: For channels that return an of MultiSensor, returns an array containing the available sensor types (of type ) that the channel supports.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.ThermistorACoefficient
member.summary: Gets and sets the A coefficient that is used in the Steinhart-Hart transfer function for the thermistor.
member.remarks: The Steinhart-Hart transfer function converts raw counts to temperature for thermistor measurements.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.ThermistorBCoefficient
member.summary: Gets and sets the B coefficient that is used in the Steinhart-Hart transfer function for the thermistor.
member.remarks: The Steinhart-Hart transfer function converts raw counts to temperature for thermistor measurements.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.ThermistorCCoefficient
member.summary: Gets and sets the C coefficient that is used in the Steinhart-Hart transfer function for the thermistor.
member.remarks: The Steinhart-Hart transfer function converts raw counts to temperature for thermistor measurements.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.RtdR0
member.summary: Gets and sets the nominal resistance of the RTD, in ohms, at 0 deg C. Set the value of this property only if the property is Custom or Pt3850 (unless you are using a 100 Ohm RTD).
member.remarks: This property is used in the Callendar-Van Dusen transfer function to convert raw counts to temperature for RTD measurements. If the is Pt3850 or Custom, specify a value of 100 (the default value), 500, or 1000 for the RtdR0 property. If the is Pt3750, a value of 1000 is used for the RtdR0 property. If the is Pt3911, a value of 100 is used for the RtdR0 property. If the is Pt3916, a value of 100 is used for the RtdR0 property. If the is Pt3920, a value of 98.129 is used for the RtdR0 property. If the is Pt3928, a value of 100 is used for the RtdR0 property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.RtdACoefficient
member.summary: Gets and sets the A coefficient that used in the Callendar-Van Dusen transfer function for the RTD. Set the value of this property only if the property is Custom.
member.remarks: The Callendar-Van Dusen transfer function converts raw counts to temperature for RTD measurements. If the is Pt3750, a value of 0.00381 is used for the RtdACoefficient property. If the is Pt3850, a value of 0.0039083 is used for the RtdACoefficient property. If the is Pt3911, a value of 0.0039692 is used for the RtdACoefficient property. If the is Pt3916, a value of 0.0039739 is used for the RtdACoefficient property. If the is Pt3920, a value of 0.0039787 is used for the RtdACoefficient property. If the is Pt3928, a value of 0.0039888 is used for the RtdACoefficient property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.RtdBCoefficient
member.summary: Gets and sets the B coefficient that is used in the Callendar-Van Dusen transfer function for the RTD. Set the value of this property only if the property is Custom.
member.remarks: The Callendar-Van Dusen transfer function converts raw counts to temperature for RTD measurements. If the is Pt3750, a value of â€“0.000000602 is used for the RtdBCoefficient property. If the is Pt3850, a value of â€“0.0000005775 is used for the RtdBCoefficient property. If the is Pt3911, a value of â€“0.00000058495 is used for the RtdBCoefficient property. If the is Pt3916, a value of â€“0.000000587 is used for the RtdBCoefficient property. If the is Pt3920, a value of â€“0.0000005869 is used for the RtdBCoefficient property. If the is Pt3928, a value of â€“0.0000005915 is used for the RtdBCoefficient property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo.RtdCCoefficient
member.summary: Gets and sets the C coefficient that is used in the Callendar-Van Dusen transfer function for the RTD. Set the value of this property only if the property is Custom.
member.remarks: The Callendar-Van Dusen transfer function converts raw counts to temperature for RTD measurements. If the is Pt3750, a value of â€“0.0000000000060 is used for the RtdCCoefficient property. If the is Pt3850, a value of â€“0.000000000004183 is used for the RtdCCoefficient property. If the is Pt3911, a value of â€“0.000000000004233 is used for the RtdCCoefficient property. If the is Pt3916, a value of â€“0.0000000000044 is used for the RtdCCoefficient property. If the is Pt3920, a value of â€“0.000000000004167 is used for the RtdCCoefficient property. If the is Pt3928, a value of â€“0.00000000000385 is used for the RtdCCoefficient property.

member.summary: Gets and sets the for the channel. Set the value of this property when the or property is Rtd, Resistance, or Thermistor.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry
member.summary: A ChannelListEntry object encapsulates a physical channel connection that is associated with a specific subsystem. A object is a collection of ChannelListEntry objects.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry.#ctor(OpenLayers.Base.SupportedChannelInfo)
member.summary: Creates and returns a ChannelListEntry object for a specified channel, based on the information for that channel.
member.remarks: If you add or insert a channel into a ChannelList by physical channel number or name (using the or methods), the ChannelListEntry object is automatically created and returned.
member.param: The object to use when creating the ChannelListEntry object.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry.SubsystemType
member.summary: Returns the subsystem type (AnalogInput, AnalogOutput, DigitalInput, DigitalOutput, CounterTimer, QuadratureDecoder, or Tachometer) for the ChannelListEntry object.
member.remarks: This information is included in the object associated with the channel.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry.SensorGain
member.summary: Returns the sensor gain value for the ChannelListEntry object.
member.remarks:
This information is included in the object associated with the channel.
By default, the sensor gain is 1. The sensor gain and offset are used to scale a sample from raw counts to a value in the engineering units of the sensor. The scaling occurs in two steps. First, the raw count value is converted to prescaled voltage using the gain applied to the input signal. Then, the prescaled voltage is scaled using the following equation: y = mx + b, where y is the scaled sensor value, m is the sensor gain, x is the prescaled value in voltage, and b is the sensor offset.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry.SensorOffset
member.summary: Returns the sensor offset value for the ChannelListEntry object.
member.remarks:
This information is included in the object associated with the channel.
By default, the sensor offset is 0. The sensor gain and offset are used to scale a sample from raw counts to a value in the engineering units of the sensor. The scaling occurs in two steps. First, the raw count value is converted to prescaled voltage using the gain applied to the input signal. Then, the prescaled voltage is scaled using the following equation: y = mx + b, where y is the scaled sensor value, m is the sensor gain, x is the prescaled value in voltage, and b is the sensor offset.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry.LogicalChannelNumber
member.summary: Returns the zero-based logical channel number for the ChannelListEntry object.
member.remarks: This information is included in the object associated with the channel.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry.LogicalChannelWord
member.summary: For channels with multi-word data (such as a 32-bit counter), returns the zero-based word number of this ChannelListEntry object. For channels without multi-word data, returns -1.
member.remarks: This information is included in the object associated with the channel.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry.PhysicalChannelNumber
member.summary: Returns the physical channel number for the ChannelListEntry object.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry.Gain
member.summary: Gets and sets the gain to apply to the input signal of the associated ChannelListEntry object.
member.remarks: The default value is 1. If the gain is not supported, the closest gain value that is supported by the subsystem is applied to the channel. Performing a get on this property after a set will return the actual gain applied to the channel.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry.Inhibit
member.summary: Gets and sets the inhibit state for the ChannelListEntry object. If True, the ChannelListEntry object takes up an entry in the and is factored into the conversion time, but data is not returned for the ChannelListEntry object. If False (the default value), data is returned for the ChannelListEntry object.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.ChannelListEntry.Name
member.summary: Gets the name of the channel that is associated with the ChannelListEntry object.
member.remarks: This information is included in the object associated with the channel.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.Clock
member.summary: The Clock class provides an interface for controlling the clock of a subsystem.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.Clock.Frequency
member.summary: Gets and sets the frequency of the internal clock source.
member.remarks: The driver sets the frequency of the internal clock as close as possible to the value that you specified in the Frequency property. You can determine the actual frequency that was set on the hardware by reading the value of the Frequency property after the subsystem has been configured (using the method).

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.Clock.Source
member.summary: Gets and sets the current clock source (Internal or External).

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.Clock.ExtClockDivider
member.summary: Gets and sets the current value of the external clock divider.
member.remarks: The external clock divider is used to determine the frequency of the external clock source. The frequency of the external clock input divided by the external clock divider determines the frequency of at which to pace the operation.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.Clock.SupportsInternalClock
member.summary: Returns True if the subsystem supports an internal clock source; otherwise, returns False.
member.remarks: Specify the clock source using the property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.Clock.SupportsExternalClock
member.summary: Returns True if the subsystem supports an external clock source; otherwise, returns False.
member.remarks: Specify the clock source using the property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.Clock.MinFrequency
member.summary: Returns the minimum allowable internal clock frequency supported by the subsystem.
member.remarks: Set the frequency of the internal clock using the property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.Clock.MaxFrequency
member.summary: Returns the maximum allowable internal clock frequency supported by the subsystem.
member.remarks: Set the frequency of the internal clock using the property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.Clock.MinExtClockDivider
member.summary: Returns the minimum allowable external clock divider value supported by the subsystem.
member.remarks: Set the external clock divider using the property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.Clock.MaxExtClockDivider
member.summary: Returns the maximum allowable external clock divider value supported by the subsystem.
member.remarks: Set the external clock divider using the property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.Clock.BaseClockFrequency
member.summary: Returns the frequency of the base clock for the subsystem.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.Clock.SupportsSimultaneousClocking
member.summary: Returns True if the subsystem supports simultaneous clocking.
member.remarks: Some subsystems allow you to read or update multiple channels on a single clock pulse. This property allows you to determine whether multiple channels can be read or updated on a single clock pulse.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.DigitalInputSubsystem.Start
member.summary: Starts a continuous operation on the digital input subsystem. Currently, only Open Layers devices that support interrupt-on-change on the digital input subsystem can perform continuous digital input operations.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.DigitalInputSubsystem.Stop
member.summary: Stops the current continuous digital input operation.

member.summary: Aborts the current continuous digital input operation.

member.summary: Returns a single data value from the digital input subsystem.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.DigitalInputSubsystem.WriteInterruptOnChangeMask(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Selects a set of digital input lines on which to perform an interrupt-on-change operation. When any of the specified bits in the interruptOnChangeMask parameter changes state, the event InterruptOnChangeEvent gets raised.
member.param: Specifies the bit mask, where each bit represents a digital input line. If a bit is set (value of 1), the event InterruptOnChangeEvent is generated when the corresponding digital line changes state. If a bit is not set (value is 0), the InterruptOnChangeEvent is not generated when the corresponding digital line changes state.
member.remarks: Use the InterruptOnChangeHandler delegate to handle the InterruptOnChangeEvent events as they occur.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.DigitalInputSubsystem.ReadInterruptOnChangeMask
member.summary: Returns a bit mask that indicates which lines within a digital input port will generate the event InterruptOnChangeEvent when they change state.
member.returns: The interrupt-on-change mask, where each bit represents a digital input line. If a bit is set, the event InterruptOnChangeEvent is generated when the corresponding digital line changes state.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.RTDType.Pt3750
member.summary: Temperature Coefficient of Resistance (TCR) value of 0.003750 Ohm / Ohm /Â° C used in the Callendar-Van Dusen transfer function for Platinum 1000 Ohm RTDs. This value is specified in the Low Cost standard. If this value is set, a value of 1000 is used for the property, a value of 0.00381 is used for the property, a value of â€“0.000000602 is used for the property, and a value of â€“0.0000000000060 is used for the property. These properties are used in the Callendar-Van Dusen equation.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.RTDType.Pt3850
member.summary: Temperature Coefficient of Resistance value of 0.003850 Ohm / Ohm /Â° C used in the Callendar-Van Dusen transfer function for Platinum 100, 500, and 1000 Ohm RTDs. This value is specified in the DIN/IEC 60751 and ASTM-E1137 standards. If this value is set, specify a value of 100, 500, or 1000 for the property. A value of 0.0039083 is used for the property, a value of â€“0.0000005775 is used for the property, and a value of â€“0.000000000004183 is used for the property. These properties are used in the Callendar-Van Dusen equation.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.RTDType.Pt3911
member.summary: Temperature Coefficient of Resistance value of 0.003911 Ohm / Ohm /Â° C used in the Callendar-Van Dusen transfer function for Platinum 100 Ohm RTDs. This value is specified in the US Industrial Standard. If this value is set, a value of 100 is used for the property, a value of 0.0039692 is used for the property, a value of â€“0.00000058495 is used for the property, and a value of â€“0.000000000004233 is used for the property. These properties are used in the Callendar-Van Dusen equation.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.RTDType.Pt3916
member.summary: Temperature Coefficient of Resistance value of 0.003916 Ohm / Ohm /Â° C used in the Callendar-Van Dusen transfer function for Platinum 100 Ohm RTDs. This value is specified in the Japanese JISC 1604-1989 standard. If this value is set, a value of 100 is used for the property, a value of 0.0039739 is used for the property, a value of â€“0.000000587 is used for the property, and a value of â€“0.0000000000044 is used for the property. These properties are used in the Callendar-Van Dusen equation.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.RTDType.Pt3920
member.summary: Temperature Coefficient of Resistance value of 0.003920 Ohm / Ohm /Â° C used in the Callendar-Van Dusen transfer equation to calculate temperature for a Platinum 100 Ohm RTDs. This value is specified in the SAMA RC21-4-1966 standard. If this value is set, a value of 98.129 is used for the property, a value of 0.0039787 is used for the property, a value of â€“0.0000005869 is used for the property, and a value of â€“0.000000000004167 is used for the property. These properties are used in the Callendar-Van Dusen equation.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.RTDType.Pt3928
member.summary: Temperature Coefficient of Resistance value of 0.003928 Ohm / Ohm /Â° C used in the Callendar-Van Dusen transfer equation to calculate temperature for a Platinum 100 Ohm RTD. If this value is set, a value of 100 is used for the property, a value of 0.0039888 is used for the property, a value of â€“0.0000005915 is used for the property, and a value of â€“0.00000000000385 is used for the property. These properties are used in the Callendar-Van Dusen equation.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.RTDType.Custom
member.summary: A user-defined value for the Temperature Coefficient of Resistance in the Callendar-Van Dusen transfer equation to calculate temperature. If this value is set, you must specify a value for the , , , and properties, which are used in the Callendar-Van Dusen equation.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.TemperatureFilterType
member.summary: Obsolete enumeration. This enum have been deprecated and may not be supported in future versions of library. Use DataFilterType enum and DataFilterType property.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.TemperatureFilterType.Raw
member.summary:
No filter. Provides fast response times, but the data may be difficult to interpret. Use when you want to filter the data yourself.
The Raw filter type returns the data exactly as it comes out of the Delta-Sigma A/D converters. Note that Delta-Sigma converters provide substantial digital filtering above the Nyquist frequency.
Generally, the only time it is desirable to use the Raw filter is if you are using fast responding thermocouples/RTDs, sampling them at higher speeds (> 1 Hz), and need as much response speed as possible.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.TemperatureFilterType.MovingAverage
member.summary:
Provides a compromise of filter functionality and response time. This filter can be used in any application.
This low-pass filter takes the previous 16 samples, adds them together, and divides by 16.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.DataFilterType
member.summary: Contains the possible values for the property in the AnalogInputSubsystem class.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.DataFilterType.Raw
member.summary:
No filter. Provides fast response times, but the data may be difficult to interpret. Use when you want to filter the data yourself.
The Raw filter type returns the data exactly as it comes out of the Delta-Sigma A/D converters. Note that Delta-Sigma converters provide substantial digital filtering above the Nyquist frequency.
Generally, the only time it is desirable to use the Raw filter is if you are using fast responding thermocouples/RTDs, sampling them at higher speeds (> 1 Hz), and need as much response speed as possible.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.DataFilterType.MovingAverage
member.summary:
Provides a compromise of filter functionality and response time. This filter can be used in any application.
This low-pass filter takes the previous 16 samples, adds them together, and divides by 16.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.ChannelType
member.summary: Contains the possible values for the property.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.ChannelType.SingleEnded
member.summary: Single-ended channel configuration. Use this configuration when you want to measure high-level signals, noise is insignificant, the source of the input is close to the device, and all the input signals are referred to the same common ground.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.ChannelType.Differential
member.summary: Differential channel configuration. Use this configuration when you want to measure low-level signals (less than 1 V), you are using an A/D converter with high resolution (greater than 12 bits), noise is a significant part of the signal, or common-mode voltage exists.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.Encoding.Binary
member.summary: Binary data encoding

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.Encoding.TwosComplement
member.summary: Twos complement data encoding

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.TriggerType
member.summary: Contains the possible values for the , , and properties.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.TriggerType.Software
member.summary: Software (internal) trigger. The trigger occurs when the method is executed.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.TriggerType.TTLPos
member.summary: An external digital (TTL) signal attached to the device. The trigger occurs when the device detects a transition on the rising edge of the digital TTL signal.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.TriggerType.DigitalEvent
member.summary: A trigger is generated when an external digital event occurs.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.TriggerType.TTLNeg
member.summary: An external digital (TTL) signal attached to the device. The trigger occurs when the device detects a transition on the falling edge of the digital TTL signal.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.TriggerType.ThresholdPos
member.summary: Either an analog signal from an analog input channel or an external analog signal attached to the device. A positive analog threshold trigger occurs when the device detects a positive-going signal that crosses a threshold value. The threshold level is generally set using an analog output subsystem on the device.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.TriggerType.ThresholdNeg
member.summary: Either an analog signal from an analog input channel or an external analog signal attached to the device. A negative analog threshold trigger occurs when the device detects a negative-going signal that crosses a threshold value. The threshold level is generally set using an analog output subsystem on the device.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.ClockSource
member.summary: Contains the possible values for the property.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.ClockSource.Internal
member.summary: The internal clock is the clock source on the device that paces data acquisition or output for each channel in the ChannelList, or that is used in a counter/timer operation.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.ClockSource.External
member.summary: An external clock source is an input signal attached to the device that paces data acquisition or output for each channel in the ChannelList, or that is used in a counter/timer operation. This clock source is useful when you want to operate at rates not available with the internal clock or if you want to operate at uneven intervals.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.GateType
member.summary: Contains the possible values for the property.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.GateType.None
member.summary: A gate type of None (software) enables the counter/timer operation immediately.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.GateType.HighLevel
member.summary: A HighLevel external gate type enables a counter/timer operation when the external gate signal is high, and disables a counter/timer operation when the external gate signal is low. Note that this gate type is used only for event counting, frequency measurement, and rate generation operations.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.GateType.LowLevel
member.summary: A LowLevel external gate type enables a counter/timer operation when the external gate signal is low, and disables the counter/timer operation when the external gate signal is high. Note that this gate type is used only for event counting, frequency measurement, and rate generation operations.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.GateType.HighEdge
member.summary: A HighEdge external gate type triggers a counter/timer operation on the transition from the low edge to the high edge (rising edge). Note that this gate type is used only for one-shot and repetitive one-shot mode.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.GateType.LowEdge
member.summary: A LowEdge external gate type triggers a counter/timer operation on the transition from the high edge to the low edge (falling edge). Note that this gate type is used only for one-shot and repetitive one-shot mode.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.GateType.Level
member.summary: A Level gate type enables a counter/timer operation on the transition from any level on the gate input signal. Note that this gate type is used only for event counting, frequency measurement, and rate generation operations.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.PulseType
member.summary: Contains the possible values for the property.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.PulseType.HighToLow
member.summary: The low portion of the total pulse output period is the active portion of the counter/timer clock output signal.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.PulseType.LowToHigh
member.summary: The high portion of the total pulse output period is the active portion of the counter/timer pulse output signal.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.EdgeType
member.summary: Contains the possible values for the property.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.EdgeType.Falling
member.summary: Falling edge of the tachometer signal.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.EdgeType.Rising
member.summary: Rising edge of the tachometer signal.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.CounterMode
member.summary: Contains the possible values for the property.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.CounterMode.Count
member.summary: Event counting mode. Use event counting mode to count events from the counterâ€™s associated clock input source.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.CounterMode.RateGenerator
member.summary: Rate generator mode. Use rate generation mode to generate a continuous pulse output signal from the counter; this mode is sometimes referred to as continuous pulse output or pulse train output.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.CounterMode.OneShot
member.summary: One-shot mode. Use one-shot mode to generate a single pulse output signal from the counter when the operation is triggered (determined by the gate input signal).

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.CounterMode.OneShotRepeat
member.summary: Repetitive one-shot mode. Use repetitive one-shot mode to generate a pulse output signal each time the device detects a trigger (determined by the gate input signal).

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.CounterMode.UpDown
member.summary: Up/down counting mode. Use up/down counting mode to increment or decrement the number of rising edges that occur on the counterâ€™s associated clock input, depending on the level of the counterâ€™s associated gate signal. If the gate signal is high, the C/T increments; if the gate signal is low, the C/T decrements.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.CounterMode.Measure
member.summary: Edge-to-edge measurement mode. Use edge-to-edge measurement to measure the time interval between a specified start edge and a specified stop edge. When the start edge is detected, the counter starts incrementing, and continues incrementing until the stop edge is detected.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.CounterMode.ContinuousMeasure
member.summary: Continuous edge-to-edge measurement mode. In continuous edge-to-edge measurement mode, the counter automatically performs an edge-to-edge measurement operation, where the counter starts incrementing when it detects the specified start edge and stops incrementing when it detects the specified stop edge. When the operation completes, the counter remains idle until it is next read. On the next read, the current value of the counter (from the previous edge-to-edge measurement operation) is returned and the next edge-to-edge measurement operation is started automatically.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.DataFlow
member.summary: Contains the possible values for the property.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.DataFlow.Continuous
member.summary: Use continuous mode when you want to acquire or output data from multiple channels continuously. For analog input operations, this is post-trigger mode. For maximum flexibility, you can specify other parameters, such as the ChannelList, clock source and frequency, buffer, and so on.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.DataFlow.SingleValue
member.summary: In a single-value operation, a single data value is read from or written to a single channel immediately, and then the operation stops. You specify only the channel to read or update, and the gain for the channel.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.DataFlow.ContinuousPreTrigger
member.summary: Use continuous pre-trigger mode when you want to continuously acquire data before a specific external trigger event occurs. For maximum flexibility, you can specify other parameters, such as the ChannelList, clock source and frequency, buffer, and so on.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.DataFlow.ContinuousPrePostTrigger
member.summary: Use continuous about-trigger mode when you want to continuously acquire data both before and after a specific external event occurs. This operation is equivalent to doing both a pre-trigger and a post-trigger acquisition For maximum flexibility, you can specify other parameters, such as the ChannelList, clock source and frequency, buffer, and so on.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.CascadeMode
member.summary: Contains the possible values for the property.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.CascadeMode.Cascade
member.summary: Internally connects or cascades the clock output signal from one counter/timer to the clock input signal of the next counter/timer, in software. In this way, you can create a 32-bit counter out of two 16-bit counters, for example.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.CascadeMode.Single
member.summary: The counter/timer is not internally connected to another counter/timer.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.PowerSource
member.summary: Contains the possible values for the property.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.PowerSource.Internal
member.summary: The device is powered by the internal system power.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.PowerSource.External
member.summary: The device is powered by an external power source.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.WrapMode.None
member.summary: The operation continues indefinitely as long as you process the buffers and put them back on the queue in a timely manner.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.WrapMode.Single
member.summary: The first buffer is reused continuously. Some devices have a FIFO onboard for analog output (waveform generation) operations. If the buffer fits into the FIFO, the device driver downloads the buffer into the FIFO on the device. The driver (or device) outputs the data starting from the first location in the buffer. When it reaches the end of the buffer, the driver (or device) continues outputting data from the first location of the buffer, and the process continues indefinitely until you stop it.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.QuadratureIndexMode.High
member.summary: If High, then the quadrature decoder resets its value to 0 whenever it detects the rising edge on the Index input signal.

member.summary: This field contains the year (1 or 2 digits), week (1 or 2 digits), test station (1 digit), and sequence number (3 digits) of the device when it was tested in Manufacturing. For example, if BoardId contains the value 5469419, this device was tested in 2005, week 46, on test station 9, and is unit number 419.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.ReferenceTriggerType.None
member.summary: Triggering is disabled.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.ReferenceTriggerType.TTLPos
member.summary: An external digital (TTL) signal attached to the device. The trigger occurs when the device detects a transition on the rising edge of the digital TTL signal.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.ReferenceTriggerType.DigitalEvent
member.summary: A trigger is generated when an external digital event occurs.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.ReferenceTriggerType.TTLNeg
member.summary: An external digital (TTL) signal attached to the device. The trigger occurs when the device detects a transition on the falling edge of the digital TTL signal.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.ReferenceTriggerType.ThresholdPos
member.summary: Either an analog signal from an analog input channel or an external analog signal attached to the device. A positive analog threshold trigger occurs when the device detects a positive-going signal that crosses a threshold value. The threshold level is generally set using an analog output subsystem on the device.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.ReferenceTriggerType.ThresholdNeg
member.summary: Either an analog signal from an analog input channel or an external analog signal attached to the device. A negative analog threshold trigger occurs when the device detects a negative-going signal that crosses a threshold value. The threshold level is generally set using an analog output subsystem on the device.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.ReferenceTriggerType.SyncBus
member.summary: An external Sync Bus signal attached to the device. For devices that support connecting multiple devices together in a master/slave relationship using Sync Bus (RJ45) connectors, the Sync Bus trigger occurs when the slave device detects a transition on the SyncBus trigger input of the Sync Bus connector.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.StrainGageBridgeConfiguration
member.summary: Contains the possible values for the property.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.StrainGageBridgeConfiguration.FullBridgeBending
member.summary: This configurations uses four active gages to measure bending strain. This configuration rejects axial strain, compensates for temperature and compensates for lead resistance.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.StrainGageBridgeConfiguration.FullBridgeBendingPoisson
member.summary: This configuration uses four active gages to measure bending strain. This configuration also rejects axial strain, compensates for temperature, compensates for lead resistance, and compensates for the aggregate effect on the principle strain measurement due to the Poisson ratio of the specimen material.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.StrainGageBridgeConfiguration.FullBridgeAxialPoisson
member.summary: This configuration uses four active gages to measure axial strain. This configuration also compensates for temperature, rejects bending strain, compensates for lead resistance, and compensates for the aggregate effect on the principle strain measurement due to the Poisson ratio of the specimen material.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.StrainGageBridgeConfiguration.HalfBridgePoisson
member.summary: This configuration uses two active gages to measure either axial or bending strain. This configuration compensates for temperature, and compensates for the aggregate effect on the principle strain measurement due to the Poisson ratio of the specimen material.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.StrainGageBridgeConfiguration.HalfBridgeBending
member.summary: This configuration uses two active gages to measure bending strain. This configuration rejects axial strain and compensates for temperature.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.StrainGageBridgeConfiguration.QuarterBridge
member.summary: This configuration uses a single active gage to measure axial or bending strain. You must supply an external resistor that matches the nominal resistance of the bridge to complete the bridge externally.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.Base.StrainGageBridgeConfiguration.QuarterBridgeTempCompensation
member.summary: This configuration uses one active gage and one dummy gage to measure axial and bending strain while compensating for temperature.

member.summary: Stops the current quadrature decoder operation.

member.summary: Stops a quadrature decoder operation. For this subsystem type, Abort behaves like .

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.QuadratureDecoderSubsystem.ReadCount
member.summary: Returns the current count of the quadrature decoder.
member.remarks:
You can read the count of the quadrature decoder to determine relative or absolute position and/or rotational speed.
For example, in an X/Y positioning application, you could use one quadrature decoder to determine the position on the X-plane, and another quadrature decoder to determine the position on the Y-plane. You can also reset the value of the decoder to 0 whenever a selected edge (high or low) of the Index signal goes high or low.
To determine the rotation of a quadrature encoder, use the following formula: Rotation degrees = Count/(4*N) x 360 degrees, where N is the number of pulses generated by the quadrature encoder per rotation. For example, if every rotation of the quadrature encoder generated 10 pulses, and the value read from the quadrature decoder is 20, the rotation of the quadrature encoder is 180 degrees (20/40 x 360 degrees).
member.returns: The current value of the quadrature decoder.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.QuadratureDecoderSubsystem.SetDefaultConfig
member.summary: set driver config struct to defaults.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.QuadratureDecoderSubsystem.Element
member.summary: Returns the element number of the subsystem.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.QuadratureDecoderSubsystem.SubsystemType
member.summary: Returns the subsystem type (QuadratureDecoder).

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.QuadratureDecoderSubsystem.SupportsQuadratureDecoder
member.summary: Returns True if the subsystem support quadrature decoder operations; otherwise, returns False.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.QuadratureDecoderSubsystem.ClockPreScale
member.summary: Gets and sets the clock prescale value for the quadrature decoder subsystem. The ClockPreScale property allows you to filter the sampling frequency of the onboard base clock by dividing down the base frequency. Values for this property range from 0 and 255, where 0 corresponds to an actual pre-scale value of 1, and 255 corresponds to an actual prescale value of 256.
member.remarks:
For quadrature decoder operations, the onboard base clock of the hardware device is used to sample the A and B inputs. Use the to get the base clock frequency that is used by your device. From a software perspective, the software considers the A and B inputs as external clock sources, therefore, you must specify the clock source as External using the property.
If you are using a device with a base clock of 36 MHz and specify a pre-scale value of 0, the resulting sampling frequency is 36 MHz (36 MHz/1). Similarly, if you specify a pre-scale value of 255 when using a device with a 48 MHz base clock, the resulting sampling frequency is 18.75 kHz (48 MHz/256).
The filter samples the incoming A and B signals twice, and when it samples a change in the state of any of these signals and the change is present for two samples, the change on the inputs is valid. A minimum of 4 clock pulses is needed to sample each edge of the A and B inputs in one cycle (for a total of 16 clock pulses). In addition, the minimum time between one edge and the next edge is 112 ns. So, if you are using a 36 MHz sample frequency, the A and B inputs can have a maximum frequency of 2.23 MHz, or a period of 448 ns.
In general, if the ClockPreScale value is set too low, the system is more susceptible to noise on the inputs. If the ClockPreScale value is set too high, counts may be missed.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.QuadratureDecoderSubsystem.X4Scaling
member.summary: Gets and sets the quadrature decoder scaling mode (X1 or X4).

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.QuadratureDecoderSubsystem.IndexMode
member.summary: Gets/sets the index mode (Disabled, Low, or High) for the quadrature decoder subsystem.

remarks.para: If you set this property to Disabled, then the Index input signal has no effect. Note that you must set the IndexMode property to Disabled if you set the property to True.
If you set this property to Low, then the quadrature decoder resets its value to 0 whenever it detects a low edge (falling edge) on the Index input signal.
If you set this property to High, then the quadrature decoder resets its value to 0 whenever it detects the high edge (rising edge) on the Index input signal.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.ReferenceTrigger
member.summary: The ReferenceTrigger class provides an interface for controlling the reference trigger of a subsystem. For devices that support a reference trigger, pre-trigger data acquisition stops and post-trigger acquisition starts when the reference trigger event occurs. Post-trigger acquisition stops when the number of samples you specify for the post-trigger scan count has been reached.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.ReferenceTrigger.TriggerType

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.ReferenceTrigger.Level
member.summary: Gets and sets the threshold value for the reference trigger. By default, the threshold value is in voltage unless specified otherwise for the device; see the user's manual for your device for valid threshold value settings for the reference trigger.
member.remarks: This propery is valid only if TriggerType property is or trigger type. The threshold level set by this property is the value after the gain is a applied to the threshold trigger channel. For example, if the voltage range of the subsystem is Â±10 V, and the specified gain is 1, specify a threshold voltage level within Â±10 V. Likewise, if the voltage range of the subsystem is Â±10 V, and the specified gain is 10, specify a threshold voltage level within Â±1 V.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.Trigger
member.summary: The Trigger class provides an interface for controlling how a subsystem is triggered. For devices that support a start trigger and a reference trigger, the Trigger class is used to set up the start trigger, which starts pre-trigger data acquisition. Use the ReferenceTrigger class to control the reference trigger.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.Trigger.Level
member.summary: Gets and sets the trigger threshold value. By default, the trigger threshold value is in voltage unless specified otherwise for the device; see the user's manual for your device for valid threshold value settings.
member.remarks: This propery is valid only if TriggerType property is or trigger type. The threshold level set by this property is the value after the gain is a applied to the threshold trigger channel. For example, if the voltage range of the subsystem is Â±10 V, and the specified gain is 1, specify a threshold voltage level within Â±10 V. Likewise, if the voltage range of the subsystem is Â±10 V, and the specified gain is 10, specify a threshold voltage level within Â±1 V.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.MultiRecordAcquisition
member.summary: The MultiRecordAcquisition class provides support for acquiring multiple records from the device.
member.remarks: To determine if your device supports multi-record acquisition, use the property.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.MultiRecordAcquisition.GetTimeStampsAsSeconds(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Returns an array of timestamps, in seconds, for records that were acquired after the start trigger occurred. The returned array contains a recordCount worth of timestamps starting with recordIndex.
member.param: The index at which to start reading the timestamp.
The number of records for which to read the timestamp. If recordCount is -1, the timestamps for all available records are returned starting at the specified recordIndex.
The actual index at which the timestamp is available for the record.
member.returns: An array of timestamps, in seconds, of the actual records that were acquired.
member.remarks: The system contains timestamps for up to 65536 (64K) records at a time. If the user does not read the records within the time that it takes to acquire 64K records, then the system overwrites old data with the new timestamps.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.Base.MultiRecordAcquisition.GetTimeStampsAsSamples(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Returns an array of timestamps, in samples, for records that were acquired after the start trigger occurred. The returned array contains a recordCount worth of timestamps starting with recordIndex.
member.param: The index at which to start reading the timestamp.
The number of records for which to read the timestamp. If recordCount is -1, the timestamps for all available records are returned starting at the specified recordIndex.
The actual index at which the timestamp is available for the record.
member.returns: An array of timestamps, in samples, of the actual records that were acquired.
member.remarks: The system contains timestamps for up to 65536 (64K) at a time. If the user does not read the records within that time that it takes to acquire 64K records, the system overwrites old data with the new timestamps.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.MultiRecordAcquisition.Enabled
member.summary: Gets and sets whether multi-record acquisition mode is enabled for the subsystem. A value of True indicates that multi-record acquisition mode is enabled, and a value of False indicates that multi-record acquisition mode is disabled.
member.remarks: To determine if your device supports multi-record acquisition, use the property. When enabled, the device acquires the number of records specified by the property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.MultiRecordAcquisition.NumRecordsToAcquire
member.summary: Gets and sets the number of records to acquire by the subsystem.
member.remarks: When it detects a trigger, the device acquires the number of samples specified in the , and then waits for the next trigger. The process is repeated until the number of records specified by the property is reached. If this property is set to zero, acquisition continues until a stop or abort is issued.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.MultiRecordAcquisition.TriggerDelayInSamples
member.summary: Gets and sets the delay, in samples, between the start trigger and start of data acquisition.
member.remarks: Refer to the user's manual for your device to determine if the subsystem supports this capability.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.MultiRecordAcquisition.RetriggerDelayInSamples
member.summary: Gets and sets the delay, in samples, between the end of the last record and acquisition of the next record.
member.remarks: Refer to the user's manual for your device to determine if the subsystem supports this capability.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.TriggeredScan
member.summary: The TriggeredScan class provides support for scanning the entries in a a specified number of times when the device detects a specified retrigger.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.TriggeredScan.Enabled
member.summary: Gets and sets whether triggered scan mode is enabled for the subsystem. A value of True indicates that triggered scan mode is enabled, and a value of False indicates that triggered scan mode is disabled.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.TriggeredScan.MultiScanCount
member.summary: Gets and sets the maximum number of scans per retrigger that are supported by the subsystem.
member.remarks: When it detects an initial trigger (pre-trigger source or post-trigger source), the device scans the a specified number of times (determined by the property), then stops. When the retrigger occurs, the process repeats.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.TriggeredScan.RetriggerSource
member.summary: Gets and sets the retrigger source (Software, TTLPos, TTLNeg, DigitalEvent, ThresholdPos, or ThresholdNeg) for the subsystem.
member.remarks: When it detects an initial trigger (pre-trigger source or post-trigger source), the device scans the a specified number of times (determined by the property), then stops. When the retrigger occurs, the process repeats. If the RetriggerSource is Software, specify the frequency of the retrigger using the property. If the RetriggerSource is any of the external trigger sources, the ChannelList is retriggered whenever the external retrigger event occurs.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.TriggeredScan.RetriggerFrequency
member.summary: Gets and sets the frequency of the internal (Software) retrigger source.
member.remarks:
When the retrigger source is Software, use this method to specify the period between retriggers. When it detects an initial trigger (pre-trigger source or post-trigger source), the device scans the a specified number of times (determined by the property), then stops. When the software retrigger occurs (determined by the RetriggerFrequency property), the process repeats.
Determine the frequency of the software retrigger as follows:
Minimum Retrigger Period = (# of CGL entries x # of CGLs per trigger)/ A/D sample clock frequency + 2 us
Maximum Retrigger Frequency = 1/Minimum Retrigger Period
For example, if you have 512 objects in the ChannelList, are scanning the channel list 256 times every trigger or retrigger, and are using an A/D sample clock with a frequency of 1 MHz, set the maximum retrigger frequency to 7.62 Hz, since 7.62 Hz = 1/((512 * 256)/1 MHz + 2 us)

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.TriggeredScan.MaxMultiScanCount
member.summary: Returns the maximum number of scans per retrigger that are supported by the subsystem.
member.remarks: Set the number of scans per retrigger using the property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.TriggeredScan.MinRetriggerFreq
member.summary: Returns the minimum retrigger frequency that is supported by the subsystem.
member.remarks: Set the retrigger frequency of the internal (Software) retrigger using the property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.TriggeredScan.MaxRetriggerFreq
member.summary: Returns the maximum retrigger frequency that is supported by the subsystem.
member.remarks: Set the retrigger frequency of the internal (Software) retrigger using the property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.TriggeredScan.SupportsInternalRetrigger
member.summary: true if subsystem supports internal retriggered scan mode (retrigger source is on the device; initial trigger is any available trigger source). otherwise false.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.TriggeredScan.SupportsScanPerTriggerRetrigger
member.summary: true if subsystem supports scan-per-trigger triggered scan mode (retrigger is the same as the initial trigger source).

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.Device.GetNumSubsystemElements(OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SubsystemType)
member.summary: Returns the number of available subsystem elements for a given subsystem type.
member.param: The type of subsystem.
member.returns: The number of elements for the specified subsystem type.
member.remarks: Your device may support multiple instances, or elements, of the same subsystem type. Element numbering is zero-based; that is, the first instance of the subsystem is called element 0, the second instance of the subsystem is called element 1, and so on. For example, if your device has two digital input ports, two subsystems of type DigitalInput are available, differentiated as elements 0 and 1.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.BufferDoneHandler
member.summary: The BufferDoneHandler delegate is called when the event BufferDoneEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the event BufferDoneEvent.
member.remarks: For input operations, the event BufferDoneEvent is raised when the internal buffer of an object has been filled with post-trigger data. For output operations, this event is raised when all the data in the internal buffer of the OlBuffer object has been output.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.DriverRunTimeErrorEventHandler
member.summary: The DriverRunTimeErrorEventHandler delegate is called when the DriverRunTimeErrorEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the DriverRunTimeErrorEvent.
member.remarks:
The DriverRunTimeErrorEvent occurs when the device driver detects one of the following error conditions during runtime:
FifoOverflow - The driver could not read data from the device FIFO (or Windows USB FIFO) fast enough, resulting in a FIFO overflow condition. To deal with this error, increase the buffer sizes, slow down the sampling rate, or stop other CPU-intensive running programs.
FifoUnderflow - The driver could not write data to the device FIFO (or Windows USB FIFO) fast enough, resulting in FIFO underflow condition. To deal with this error, increase the buffer sizes, slow down the sampling rate, or stop other CPU-intensive running programs.
DeviceOverClocked - The A/D clock (usually external clock) is running too fast on the device. To deal with this error, slow down the A/D clock.
TriggerError - The driver detected a trigger on the device but did not act on it.
DeviceError - Generated by the driver due to a USB bus or hardware problem. To deal with this error, stop connecting/disconnecting USB devices while streaming data to them.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.QueueDoneHandler
member.summary: The QueueDoneHandler delegate is called when the event QueueDoneEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the event QueueDoneEvent.
member.remarks: The event QueueDoneEvent is raised when no objects are available on the queue and the operation stops.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.QueueStoppedHandler
member.summary: The QueueStoppedHandler delegate is called when the event QueueStoppedEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the event QueueStoppedEvent.
member.remarks: A QueueStoppedEvent is raised when Stop or Abort is called for a continuous analog I/O operation. The event BufferDoneEvent is generated for the current buffer and for up to eight inprocess buffers before a QueueStoppedEvent event occurs.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.PreTriggerBufferDoneHandler
member.summary: The PreTriggerBufferDoneHandler delegate is called when the event PreTriggerBufferDoneEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the event PreTriggerBufferDoneEvent.
member.remarks: The event PreTriggerBufferDone is raised when the internal buffer of an object is filled with pre-trigger data (for an input operation only).

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.IOCompleteHandler
member.summary: The IOCompleteHandler delegate is called when the event IOCompleteEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the event IOCompleteEvent.
member.remarks:
For analog input operations that use a reference trigger whose trigger type is something other than software (none), the event IOCompleteEvent is raised when the last post-trigger sample is copied into the user buffer. Devices that do not support a reference trigger will never receive this event for analog input operations.
For analog output operations, the event IOCompleteEvent is raised when the last data point has been output from an analog output channel; in some cases, this event is raised well after the data is transferred from the buffer (and, therefore, well after the events BufferDoneEvent and QueueDoneEvents are raised).

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.GeneralFailureHandler
member.summary: The GeneralFailureHandler delegate is called when the event GeneralFailureEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the event GeneralFailureEvent.
member.remarks: The event GeneralFailureEvent is raised when a general library failure occurs.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.DeviceRemovedHandler
member.summary: The DeviceRemovedHandler delegate is called when the event DeviceRemovedEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the event DeviceRemovedEvent.
member.remarks: The event DeviceRemovedEvent is raised when a device is removed from your system while your application is running.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.BufferDoneEventArgs
member.summary: A BufferDoneEventArgs object is passed to one of the following delegates when the associated event occurs: delegate when the event BufferDoneEvent occurs or delegate when the event PreTriggerBufferDoneEvent occurs. BufferDoneEventArgs contains the data that is associated with the event, including the subsystem that raised the event, the time stamp of when the event occurred, and the completed object.
member.remarks:
For input operations, the event BufferDoneEvent is raised when the internal buffer of an object has been filled with post-trigger data. For output operations, this event is raised when all the data in the internal buffer of an object has been output.
If you stop an analog I/O operation, the event BufferDoneEvent is generated for the current OlBuffer object and for up to eight inprocess OlBuffer objects before a QueueStoppedEvent event occurs.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.GeneralEventArgs
member.summary: GeneralEventArgs is the base class for all event data. GeneralEventArgs contains the data that is passed to all events, including the subsystem that raised the event, and the time stamp of when the event occurred.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.GeneralEventArgs.DateTime
member.summary: Returns the time stamp of when the associated event occurred.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.GeneralEventArgs.Subsystem
member.summary: Returns the subsystem that raised the event.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.BufferDoneEventArgs.OlBuffer
member.summary: Returns the completed object.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.IOCompleteEventArgs
member.summary: An IOCompleteEventArgs object is passed to the delegate when the event IOCompleteEvent occurs. IOCompleteEventArgs contains the data associated with the event IOCompleteEvent. For analog input operations, this includes the total number of samples per channel that were acquired from the time acquisition was started to the last post-trigger sample, and the subsystem that raised the event. For analog output operations, this is the subsystem that raised the event.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.IOCompleteEventArgs.LastSampleNumber
member.summary: (For analog input operations only) returns the total number of samples per channel that were acquired from the time acquisition was started (with the start trigger) to the last post-trigger sample.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.DriverRunTimeErrorEventArgs
member.summary: A DriverRunTimeErrorEventArgs object is passed to the delegate when when the event DriverRunTimeErrorEvent occurs. DriverRunTimeErrorEventArgs contains the error/warning that is generated by the device driver, an error message that describes the error/warning, the subsystem that raised the event, and the time stamp of when the event occurred.
member.remarks:
The DriverRunTimeErrorEvent occurs when the device driver detects one of the following error conditions:
FifoOverflow - The driver could not read data from the device FIFO (or Windows USB FIFO) fast enough, resulting in a FIFO overflow condition. To deal with this error, increase the buffer sizes, slow down the sampling rate, or stop other CPU-intensive running programs.
FifoUnderflow - The driver could not write data to the device FIFO (or Windows USB FIFO) fast enough, resulting in FIFO underflow condition. To deal with this error, increase the buffer sizes, slow down the sampling rate, or stop other CPU-intensive running programs.
DeviceOverClocked - The A/D clock (usually external clock) is running too fast on the device. To deal with this error, slow down the A/D clock.
TriggerError - The driver detected a trigger on the device but did not act on it.
DeviceError - Generated by the driver due to a USB bus or hardware problem. To deal with this error, stop connecting/disconnecting USB devices while streaming data to them.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.DriverRunTimeErrorEventArgs.ErrorCode
member.summary: Returns the from the Open Layers for .NET Class Library that is associated with the driver error.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.DriverRunTimeErrorEventArgs.Message
member.summary: Returns the descriptive string for the driver error.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.BufferProcessorThread
member.summary: The BufferProcessorThread class is used to process an object by merging the data into the appropriate portion of an object. A separate BufferProcessorThread is needed for each device in a device collection and the thread is woken up to process the buffer when a BufferDoneEvent occurs on the given device or when a buffer is dequeued from the subsytem's buffer queue.
