member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SubsystemBase.Element
member.summary: Returns the element number of the subsystem.
member.remarks: Your device may support multiple instances, called elements, of the same subsystem type. Element numbering is zero-based; that is, the first instance of the subsystem is called element 0, the second instance of the subsystem is called element 1, and so on. For example, if your device has two digital input ports, two subsystems of type DigitalInput are available, differentiated as elements 0 and 1.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SubsystemBase.State
member.summary: Returns the current state of the subsystem (Initialized, ConfiguredForSingleValue, ConfiguredForContinuous, PreStarted, Running, Stopping, Aborting, or IoComplete).

member.name: E:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SubsystemBase.GeneralFailureEvent
member.summary: Occurs when a general library failure is encountered.

member.name: E:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SubsystemBase.DeviceRemovedEvent
member.summary: Occurs when a device is removed from your system while your application is running.

member.name: E:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SubsystemBase.QueueDoneEvent
member.summary: Occurs when no OlBuffer objects are available on the queue and the operation stops.

member.name: E:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SubsystemBase.QueueStoppedEvent
member.summary: For analog input operations, occurs when a pre- or post-trigger acquisition operation completes or when you stop a continuous analog input operation. For analog output operations, occurs when a continuous analog output operation stops and the queue is emptied.

member.name: E:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SubsystemBase.BufferDoneEvent
member.summary: For input operations, occurs when the OlBuffer object has been filled with post-trigger data. For output operations, occurs when all the data in the OlBuffer object has been output. If you stop an analog I/O operation, the event BufferDoneEvent is generated for the current buffer and for up to eight inprocess buffers before a QueueStoppedEvent event occurs.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SubsystemBase.SubsystemType
member.summary: Returns the subsystem type (AnalogInput or AnalogOutput).

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SubsystemBase.StopOnError
member.summary: Gets or sets the stop-on-error condition (stop if overrun or underrun occurs, or continue if overrun or underrun occurs).
member.remarks: If StopOnError is True, the subsystem automatically stops when an overrun or underrun error occurs. If StopOnError is False, the subsystem continues to run when an overrun or underrun error occurs.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SubsystemBase.AsynchronousStop
member.summary: Gets or sets the stop behavior (synchronous or asynchronous) of the subsystem.
member.remarks: If you set the AsynchronousStop property to True, control returns to your program after is called. If you set the AsynchronousStop property to False (the default setting), control does not return to your program after Stop is called until the object completes. (It is recommended that you do not wait more than 20 seconds for the stop to complete.) If you try to perform another operation while the stop is in progress, an exception is raised with the error code "SubsystemStopping" and the exception message "The subsystem is in the process of stopping or aborting".

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.AnalogSubsystem.VoltsToRawValue(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Converts a voltage value into a raw count.
member.param: The voltage value to convert.
The gain that was applied to input signal to produce the voltage.
member.returns: The raw count that is associated with the voltage value.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.AnalogSubsystem.RawValueToVolts(System.UInt16,System.Double)
member.summary: Converts a raw count into a voltage value.
member.param: The raw count to convert.
The gain to apply to the value. The gain is typically applied to the input signal at acquisition time.
member.returns: The voltage value that is associated with the raw count.
member.remarks: Use this method when the subsystem has a resolution of 16 bits or less.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.AnalogSubsystem.RawValueToVolts(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Converts a raw count into a voltage value.
member.param: The raw count to convert.
The gain to apply to the value. The gain is typically applied to the input signal at acquisition time.
member.returns: The voltage value that is associated with the raw count.
member.remarks: Use this method when the subsystem has a resolution of greater than 16 bits.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.AnalogSubsystem.RawValueToSensor(System.UInt16,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Converts a raw count to a sensor value in engineering units.
member.param: The raw count to convert.
The gain of the input signal, which is used to convert the raw count to a prescaled voltage value.
The sensor gain that is applied to the prescaled voltage value.
The sensor offset that is applied to the prescaled voltage value.
member.returns: The sensor value that is associated with the raw count.
member.remarks:
Use this method when the subsystem has a resolution of 16 bits or less.
The scaling occurs in two steps. First, the raw count is converted to a prescaled voltage by applying the gain for the input signal. Then, the prescaled voltage value is scaled using the equation y = mx + b, where y is the scaled sensor value, m is the sensor gain, x is the prescaled value in voltage, and b is the sensor offset.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.AnalogSubsystem.RawValueToSensor(System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Converts a raw count to a sensor value in engineering units.
member.param: The raw count to convert.
The gain of the input signal, which is used to convert the raw count to a prescaled voltage value.
The sensor gain that is applied to the prescaled voltage value.
The sensor offset that is applied to the prescaled voltage value.
member.returns: The sensor value that is associated with the raw count.
member.remarks:
Use this method when the subsystem has a resolution greater than 16 bits.
The scaling occurs in two steps. First, the raw count is converted to a prescaled voltage by applying the gain for the input signal. Then, the prescaled voltage value is scaled using the equation y = mx + b, where y is the scaled sensor value, m is the sensor gain, x is the prescaled value in voltage, and b is the sensor offset.

member.name: E:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.AnalogSubsystem.IOCompleteEvent
member.summary: Occurs when the last data point has been output from an analog output channel, or when the last sample has been copied to an analog input buffer on devices that support TTL and analog threshold stop trigger. In some cases, this event is raised well after the data is transferred from the buffer (and, therefore, well after BufferDoneEvent and QueueDoneEvents occur).

member.name: E:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.AnalogSubsystem.DriverRunTimeErrorEvent
member.summary: Occurs when the device driver detects one of the following error conditions during runtime: FifoOverflow, FifoUnderflow, DeviceOverClocked, TriggerError, or DeviceError. See for more information.

member.remarks: Use the property to set the range.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.AnalogSubsystem.SupportedVoltageRanges

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.AnalogSubsystem.QueuedBufferDones
member.summary: Returns the number of Buffer Done Events queued to be sent when is true.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.AnalogSubsystem.SynchronousBufferDone
member.summary: Gets or sets the way Buffer Done events are executed (asynchronously or synchronously). If False, each Buffer Done event is executed asynchronously in its own thread. If True, all Buffer Done events are executed synchronously from a single worker thread.
member.remarks: If your program is running under a heavy CPU load and this property is False, .NET may call your Buffer Done delegates out of order under certain circumstances. To avoid this problem, it is recommended that you set this property to True.

member.remarks: This method overrides the Abort method in the base class.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.AnalogInputSubsystem.GetSingleValueAsVolts(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Acquires a single value from an analog input channel and returns the data in voltage.
member.param: The physical analog input channel to sample.
The gain to apply to the input signal.
member.returns: The acquired value in voltage.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.AnalogInputSubsystem.GetSingleValueAsSensor(System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Acquires a single value from an analog input channel and returns it in the engineering units of the specified sensor.
member.param: Physical analog input channel to sample.
Gain to apply to the input signal to get the prescaled voltage value.
Sensor gain value to apply to the prescaled voltage value. The default value is 1.
Sensor offset value to apply to the prescaled voltage value. The default value is 0.
member.returns: The scaled value in the engineering units of the sensor.
member.remarks: The sensor gain and offset are used to scale a sample from raw counts to a sensor format. The scaling occurs in two steps. First, the raw count value is acquired and converted to prescaled voltage using the gain applied to the channel. Then, the sensor gain and sensor offset parameters are applied to the prescaled voltage value using the linear equation y = mx + b, where y is the sensor value, m is the sensor gain, x is the prescaled value in voltage, and b is the sensor offset.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.AnalogInputSubsystem.GetSingleValueAsRaw(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Acquires a single value from an analog input channel and returns it in raw counts.
member.param: Physical analog input channel to sample.
Gain to apply to the input signal.
member.returns: The analog input value in raw counts.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.AnalogInputSubsystem.GetOneBuffer(OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannelInfo,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Using continuous acquisition, acquires a buffer of data NumberOfSample long from the specified channel. This method uses the current clock frequency, trigger, etc., for the acquisition. This method is synchronous and returns only after the requested data has been acquired or a calculated timeout value has been exceeded.
member.param: object, which represents the channel from which to acquire data.
Number of samples to acquire
Timeout value, in milliseconds, to wait for buffer completion. A value of -1 means the timeout is infinite.
member.returns: An object with the specified number of samples.
member.remarks: This method allocates a buffer and starts the continuous analog input operation automatically using the current configuration of the analog input subsystem. This method is synchronous and returns only after the requested data has been acquired or the specified timeout value, in milliseconds, has been exceeded. No BufferDoneEvents occur. If the buffer is not filled before the specified timeout value is exceeded, AnalogInputSubsystem.Abort is called and a TimeoutException is raised. If a GeneralFailureEvent or DriverRuntimeErrorEvent occurs during acquisition, an OlException with the appropriate error code is raised. Once the buffer is returned, you can copy the data from the buffer into an array using the OlBuffer methods.

member.name: E:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.AnalogInputSubsystem.PreTriggerBufferDoneEvent

member.summary: For subsystems that support simultaneous operations ( is True), outputs a single raw count on each analog output channel that is specified in the singleValuesInfo array. If an analog output channel is not specified in this array, the value of the output channel will not change; the output channel maintains the last value that was written to it.
member.param: An array of structures, which specify the analog output channels to update and the raw count value to output on each channel.
member.remarks: The resulting output will not be synchronized. If synchronization is required, use and to generate the required output.

member.summary: For subsystems that support simultaneous operations ( is True), outputs a single voltage value on each analog output channel that is specified in the singleValuesInfo array. If an analog output channel is not specified in this array, the value of the output channel will not change; the output channel maintains the last value that was written to it.
member.param: An array of structures, which specify the analog output channels to update and the voltage value to output on each channel.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer
member.summary: The OlBuffer class encapsulates a data buffer that is used in a continuous I/O operation.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer.#ctor(System.Int32,OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.AnalogSubsystem)
member.summary: Creates and returns an OlBuffer object, and allocates an internal data buffer that will contain a specified number of samples.
member.param: Maximum number of samples that the internal buffer can contain. This parameter determines the size of the internal buffer.
The subsystem (AnalogInputSubsystem or AnalogOutputSubsystem) with which the OlBuffer object is initially associated.
member.remarks:
The values for voltage range, channel list, data encoding, and resolution that are applied to the OlBuffer object are determined by the subsystem with which it is associated. Initially (and by default), these values are determined by the subsystem that is specified in the constructor above.
If, however, you later use the OlBuffer object with a different subsystem type, these values are determined by subsystem with which it is used. For example, if the OlBuffer object was initially associated with an analog output subsystem, and then put on an analog input subsystem queue, the values for voltage range, channel list, data encoding, and resolution will be updated to reflect the settings of the analog input subsystem when the OlBuffer object is completed by the device driver.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer.Finalize
member.summary: Object Finalize method.

member.summary: Reallocates the internal data buffer of the OlBuffer object to contain the specified number of samples. The existing internal data buffer is deallocated and any data that it contained is lost.
member.param: Maximum number of samples that the internal data buffer can contain. This parameter determines the size of the internal buffer.
member.returns: True if allocation was successful; otherwise, returns False.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer.GetDataAsVoltsByte(OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ChannelListEntry,System.Int32)
member.summary: For a specified ChannelListEntry, converts the data from the internal buffer of an OlBuffer object into voltage values, and then copies these voltage values into a user-declared array of bytes. Each voltage value is stored as an Int32, and takes 4 bytes.
member.param: object, which represents the channel whose data you want to convert and copy.
The amount by which to scale each voltage value. By default, this is 1.
member.returns: An array of voltage values that is associated with a specified ChannelListEntry, represented as bytes.
member.remarks: This method converts only the data associated with a specified ChannelListEntry in the buffer into voltage values, and then copies this data into a user-declared array of bytes. Note that if the ChannelListEntry occurs more than once in the buffer, the data for each occurrence of the ChannelListEntry is converted and copied.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer.GetDataAsRawByte
member.summary: Copies the data, as raw counts, from the internal buffer of the OlBuffer object into a user-declared array of bytes.
member.returns: An array of raw counts represented as bytes.
member.remarks: This method copies all the data, as raw counts, from the internal buffer into a user-declared array of bytes. This method is useful for file I/O operations. Since each sample takes more than one array entry, other uses may be limited.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer.GetDataAsRawByte(OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ChannelListEntry)
member.summary: Copies only the data associated with a specified ChannelListEntry, as raw counts, from the internal buffer of the OlBuffer object into a user-declared array of bytes.
member.param: object, which represents the channel whose data you want to copy.
member.returns: An array of raw counts that are associated with a specified ChannelListEntry, represented as bytes.
member.remarks: Note that if the ChannelListEntry occurs more than once in the OlBuffer object, the data for each occurrence of the ChannelListEntry is copied. This method is useful for file I/O operations. Since each sample takes more than one array entry, other uses may be limited.

member.remarks: This method copies all the data, as raw counts, from the internal buffer of the OlBuffer object into a user-declared array of unsigned 16-bit integers (ushort).

member.returns: Returns a user-specified array of voltage values, represented as 64-bit floating-point values (double).
member.remarks: This method copies all the data, as voltages, from the internal buffer of an OlBuffer object into a user-declared array of 64-bit floating-point values (double).

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer.SampleAt(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the raw count value at the specified index of the internal buffer that is encapsulated by the OlBuffer object.
member.param: The zero-based index number of the internal buffer.
member.returns: The raw count value. This value is represented as a signed, 32-bit integer (int).

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer.GetDataAsRpm(OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ChannelListEntry,System.Int32)
member.summary: For a specified ChannelListEntry, converts the tachometer data from the internal buffer of an OlBuffer object into RPM values, and then copies these values into a user-declared array of 64-bit floating-point (double) values.
member.param: object, which represents the channel whose data you want to convert and copy.
Specifies the number of pulses per revolution for the tachometer.
member.returns: An array of RPM values, represented as 64-bit floating-point (double) values, that are associated with a specified ChannelListEntry.
member.remarks: This method raises an exception if the is not a tachometer.

member.param: The index of the device.
The state to set the device buffer complete flag to.
member.returns: The collection buffer complete status.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the data, as a raw count, at the specified index in the internal buffer of the OlBuffer object.
member.returns: The raw count, represented as a signed, 32-bit integer (int).

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer.SampleSizeInBytes
member.summary: Returns the size, in bytes, of the samples in the internal buffer of the OlBuffer object.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer.ValidSamples
member.summary: Returns the number of valid samples in the internal buffer of the OlBuffer object.
member.remarks:
For analog input operations, the ValidSamples property is set to the number of samples in the completed buffer under normal circumstances. However, in some cases, like if is called in the middle of an operation, ValidSamples reflects the number of samples in the buffer when Abort was called. In addition, if Abort or is called, any OlBuffer objects whose state is Inprocess will have a ValidSamples of 0.
For analog output operations, ValidSamples is always equal to the maximum number of samples that the buffer was allocated to hold.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer.InternalValidSamples
member.summary: This is the same property as ValidSamples except that we use it internally as R/W

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer.BufferSizeInSamples
member.summary: Returns the size of the internal data buffer, in samples.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer.BufferState
member.summary: Contains the possible values for the state of an object.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer.BufferState.Idle
member.summary: The OlBuffer object has been created, but has not been queued to a subsystem.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer.BufferState.Queued
member.summary: The OlBuffer object has been queued to a subsystem.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer.BufferState.InProcess
member.summary: The OlBuffer object has been sent to the device driver for processing. A maximum of eight OlBuffer objects can be in process at one time.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer.BufferState.Completed
member.summary: For an input operation, the internal buffer of the OlBuffer object has been filled with data, and has not been put back on the queue for the subsystem. For an output operation, all the data in the internal buffer of the OlBuffer object has been output, and the OlBuffer object has not been put back on the queue for the subsystem.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer.BufferState.Released
member.summary: The internal buffer of the OlBuffer object has been deallocated.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.BufferQueue
member.summary: The BufferQueue class provides an interface for queuing objects to a device's subsystem for continuous I/O operations.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.BufferQueue.QueueBuffer(OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.OlBuffer)
member.summary: Adds an object to the subsystem queue.
member.remarks: If the subsystem is incompatible with the specified object, an exception is raised.
member.param: The object to add to the subsystem queue.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.BufferQueue.DequeueBuffer
member.summary: Removes the object from the front of the subsystem queue, and returns it to the user.
member.returns: The object from the front of the queue.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.BufferQueue.FreeAllQueuedBuffers
member.summary: Removes all objects from the subsystem queue and deallocates the associated internal buffer.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.BufferQueue.QueuedCount
member.summary: Returns the number of objects that are on the subsystem queue (OlBuffer objects are in the queued state).
member.remarks: When you start a continuous operation, the device takes up to eight OlBuffer objects from the subsystem queue and begins filling the associated internal buffers (for input operations) or outputting data from the associated internal buffers (for output operations) at the specified clock rate. The state of these OlBuffer objects changes from queued to inprocess. Every time an OlBuffer object transitions from the queued state to the inprocess state, the value of the QueuedCount property decreases by one and the value of the InProcessCount property increases by 1. For example, assume that you call QueueBuffer for 10 OlBuffer objects; the QueuedCount is now 10 and the InProcessCount is 0. Once you call Start, up to 8 OlBuffer objects are moved from the queued state to the inprocess state. The QueuedCount is now 2 and the InProcessCount is now 8. As each OlBuffer object is completed, an event is generated allowing you to process the buffer. Assume that you do not put the OlBuffer objects back on the queue after processing them. In this case, the QueuedCount decreases while the InProcessCount remains the same (as a new inprocess OlBuffer object replaces a completed OlBuffer object) until the QueuedCount gets to 0, then the InProcessCount starts decreasing until all the OlBuffer objects are completed.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.BufferQueue.InProcessCount
member.summary: Returns the number of objects that have been taken from subsystem queue and sent to the device for processing (buffers are in the inprocess state).
member.remarks: When you start a continuous operation, the device takes up to eight OlBuffer objects from the subsystem queue and begins filling the associated internal buffers (for input operations) or outputting data from the associated internal buffers for output operations) at the specified clock rate. The state of these OlBuffer objects changes from queued to inprocess. Every time an OlBuffer object transitions from the queued state to the inprocess state, the value of the QueuedCount property decreases by one and the value of the InProcessCount property increases by 1. For example, assume that you call QueueBuffer for 10 OlBuffer objects; the QueuedCount is now 10 and the InProcessCount is 0. Once you call Start, up to 8 OlBuffer objects are moved from the queued state to the inprocess state. The QueuedCount is now 2 and the InProcessCount is now 8. As each OlBuffer object is completed, an event is generated allowing you to process the buffer. Assume that you do not put the OlBuffer objects back on the queue after processing them. In this case, the QueuedCount decreases while the InProcessCount remains the same (as a new inprocess OlBuffer object replaces a completed OlBuffer object) until the QueuedCount gets to 0, then the InProcessCount starts decreasing until all the OlBuffer objects are completed.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ChannelList
member.summary: A ChannelList specifies a collection of objects for use in a continuous I/O operation. Each ChannelListEntry object encapsulates a physical channel connection for a specific subsystem.
member.remarks: A ChannelList is typically used in continuous analog input and analog output operations. You can add and/or insert a channel to the ChannelList by physical channel number, by name, or as a ChannelListEntry object.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ChannelList.Add(System.Int32)
member.summary: Adds a channel to the end of the ChannelList.
member.param: The number of the physical channel on the specified subsystem to add to the ChannelList.
member.returns: A object for the physical channel that was added. You can then access this ChannelListEntry object through the ChannelList for the subsystem.
member.remarks:
Adds a channel, specified as a physical channel number, to the end of the ChannelList and returns a object for the channel.
This method provides a simple way to add channels into the ChannelList, particularly if you are adding channels that are native to the subsystem type (such as analog input channels on an analog input subsystem). For native channels, the physical channel number always equals the logical channel number. While non-native channels, such as digital inputs that are streamed through the analog input subsystem, can also be added this way, the physical channel number is not the same as the logical channel number, so you may find it easier to add a channel by name or by object instead.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ChannelList.Insert(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Inserts a channel at the specified index of the ChannelList.
member.param: Zero-based index of the ChannelList at which to insert the object.
The physical channel number of the specified subsystem to add to the ChannelList.
member.returns: A object for the physical channel that was inserted. You can then access this ChannelListEntry object through the ChannelList for the subsystem.
member.remarks:
Inserts a channel, specified as a physical channel number, at the specified index of the ChannelList and returns a object for the channel.
This method provides a simple way to insert channels into the ChannelList, particularly if you are inserting channels that are native to the subsystem type (such as analog input channels on an analog input subsystem). For native channels, the physical channel number always equals the logical channel number. While non-native channels, such as digital inputs that are streamed through the analog input subsystem, can also be inserted this way, the physical channel number is not the same as the logical channel number, so you may find it easier to insert a channel by name or by object instead.

member.remarks: Adds the specified object to the end of the ChannelList.
member.param: object to add to the ChannelList.
member.returns: The index at which the ChannelListEntry object has been added to the ChannelList.

The object to insert.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannels
member.summary: The SupportedChannels class describes, through a collection of objects, the channels available for a particular subsystem.
member.remarks: It is often the case that a subsystem of one type is capable of including data in its data stream from a different subsystem type. For example, an analog input subsystem, which has its own native analog input channels, may also stream data from non-native channels, such as a digital input port or counter/timer channel. Typically, these non-native channels are described in a channel list with numbers beyond the range of its native channels. The Open Layers for .NET Class Library allows you to deal with non-native channels more easily by describing channels in terms of subsystem type and logical channel numbers or channel names.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannels.GetChannelInfo(OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SubsystemType,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a SupportedChannelInfo object for the specified subsystem type and logical channel number.
member.remarks: If the channel has multiple logical channel words, this method returns the SupportedChannelInfo object for logical channel word 0.
member.param: Subsystem type.
Logical channel number for the subsystem type.
member.returns: SupportedChannelInfo object associated with the specified channel.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannels.GetChannelInfo(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the SupportedChannelInfo object for the specified channel name.
member.remarks: If the channel has multiple logical channel words, this method returns the SupportedChannelInfo object for logical channel word 0.
member.param: Channel name
member.returns: SupportedChannelInfo object associated with the specified channel.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannels.GetChannelInfo(OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SubsystemType,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the SupportedChannelInfo object for the specified subsystem type, logical channel, and logical channel word.
member.remarks: For channels like 32-bit counter/timers that return multi-word data, the logical channel word, which is zero-based, maps the physical channel to the data word that it returns. For example, a logical channel word of 0 indicates that this channel returns the first 16-bits of data. A logical channel word of 1 indicates that this channel returns the second 16-bits of data. For channels that do not return multi-word data, the value of the logical channel word is -1.
member.param: Subsystem type.
Logical channel number for the subsystem type.
Logical channel word for the specified logical channel number.
member.returns: SupportedChannelInfo object associated with the logical channel word.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannels.GetChannelInfo(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the SupportedChannelInfo object for the specified physical channel number.
member.remarks: If the channel has multiple logical channel words, this method returns the SupportedChannelInfo object for logical channel word 0.
member.param: Physical channel number of the subsystem.
member.returns: SupportedChannelInfo object associated with the specified channel.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannels.Item(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the object at the specified index ([index]) of the object.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannels.Count
member.summary: Returns the number of objects in the SupportedChannels collection.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannelInfo
member.summary: The SupportedChannelInfo class describes a specific channel of a subsystem. You access a SupportedChannelInfo object using the class.
member.remarks: When you get a subsystem of a specified type, the software automatically determines the number of available channels for the subsystem and creates a SupportedChannelInfo object for each channel, containing the following information: physical channel number, logical channel number, logical channel word, channel name, sensor gain, and sensor offset.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannelInfo.Subsystem
member.summary: Returns the subsystem object (, , that is associated with this channel.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannelInfo.PhysicalChannelNumber
member.summary: Returns the physical channel number that is associated with this channel.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannelInfo.LogicalChannelNumber
member.summary: Returns the zero-based logical channel number that is associated with this channel.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannelInfo.Name
member.summary: Gets and sets the name of the associated channel.
member.remarks: Each SupportedChannelInfo object in a SupportedChannels collection object must have a unique name. By default, the channels have the following names, which you can modify, if you wish: For analog input channels, the channels are named Ain0, Ain1, and so on. For analog output channels, the channels are named Aout0, Aout1, and so on. For digital input channels, the channels are named Din0, Din1, and so on. For counter/timer channels, the channels are named CT0 Word 0, CT0 Word 1, CT1 Word 0, CT1 Word 1, and so on. For quadrature decoder channels, the channels are named Quad0 Word 0, Quad0 Word 1, Quad1 Word 0, Quad1 Word 1, and so on.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannelInfo.SubsystemType
member.summary: Returns the type of subsystem (AnalogInput, AnalogOutput, DigitalInput, DigitalOutput, CounterTimer, or QuadratureDecoder) that is associated with this channel.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannelInfo.LogicalChannelWord
member.summary: For channels with multi-word data (such as a 32-bit counter), returns the zero-based word number that is associated with this channel. For channels without multi-word data, returns -1.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannelInfo.SensorGain
member.summary: Gets and sets the gain value to apply to the sensor that is connected to this channel.
member.remarks: By default, the sensor gain is 1. The sensor gain and offset are used to scale a sample from raw counts to a value in the engineering units of the sensor. The scaling occurs in two steps. First, the raw count value is converted to prescaled voltage using the gain applied to the input signal. Then, the prescaled voltage is scaled using the following equation: y = mx + b, where y is the scaled sensor value, m is the sensor gain, x is the prescaled value in voltage, and b is the sensor offset.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannelInfo.SensorOffset
member.summary: Gets and sets the offset value to apply to the sensor that is connected to this channel.
member.remarks: By default, the sensor offset is 0. The sensor gain and offset are used to scale a sample from raw counts to a value in the engineering units of the sensor. The scaling occurs in two steps. First, the raw count value is converted to prescaled voltage using the gain applied to the input signal. Then, the prescaled voltage is scaled using the following equation: y = mx + b, where y is the scaled sensor value, m is the sensor gain, x is the prescaled value in voltage, and b is the sensor offset.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannelInfo.Coupling
member.summary: Gets and sets the to apply to the channel.
member.remarks: By default, DC coupling is selected for all channels.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannelInfo.ExcitationCurrentSource
member.summary: Gets and sets the to apply to the channel.
member.remarks: By default, the excitation current source is disabled for all channels.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannelInfo.ExcitationCurrentValue
member.summary: Gets and sets the value of the excitation current source to apply to the channel.
member.remarks: This value is applicable only when the excitation current source is internal.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.SupportedChannelInfo.IOType
member.summary: Gets the measurement that is supported by the channel.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ChannelListEntry

member.summary: Creates and returns a ChannelListEntry object for a specified channel, based on the information for that channel.
member.remarks: If you add or insert a channel into a ChannelList by physical channel number or name (using the or methods), the ChannelListEntry object is automatically created and returned.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ChannelListEntry.SensorGain
member.summary: Returns the sensor gain value for the ChannelListEntry object.
member.remarks:
This information is included in the object associated with the channel.
By default, the sensor gain is 1. The sensor gain and offset are used to scale a sample from raw counts to a value in the engineering units of the sensor. The scaling occurs in two steps. First, the raw count value is converted to prescaled voltage using the gain applied to the input signal. Then, the prescaled voltage is scaled using the following equation: y = mx + b, where y is the scaled sensor value, m is the sensor gain, x is the prescaled value in voltage, and b is the sensor offset.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ChannelListEntry.SensorOffset
member.summary: Returns the sensor offset value for the ChannelListEntry object.
member.remarks:
This information is included in the object associated with the channel.
By default, the sensor offset is 0. The sensor gain and offset are used to scale a sample from raw counts to a value in the engineering units of the sensor. The scaling occurs in two steps. First, the raw count value is converted to prescaled voltage using the gain applied to the input signal. Then, the prescaled voltage is scaled using the following equation: y = mx + b, where y is the scaled sensor value, m is the sensor gain, x is the prescaled value in voltage, and b is the sensor offset.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ChannelListEntry.LogicalChannelNumber
member.summary: Returns the zero-based logical channel number for the ChannelListEntry object.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ChannelListEntry.LogicalChannelWord
member.summary: For channels with multi-word data (such as a 32-bit counter), returns the zero-based word number of this ChannelListEntry object. For channels without multi-word data, returns -1.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ChannelListEntry.PhysicalChannelNumber

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ChannelListEntry.Gain
member.summary: Gets and sets the gain to apply to the input signal of the associated ChannelListEntry object.
member.remarks: The default value is 1. If the gain is not supported, the closest gain value that is supported by the subsystem is applied to the channel. Performing a get on this property after a set will return the actual gain applied to the channel.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ChannelListEntry.Inhibit
member.summary: Gets and sets the inhibit state for the ChannelListEntry object. If True, the ChannelListEntry object takes up an entry in the and is factored into the conversion time, but data is not returned for the ChannelListEntry object. If False (the default value), data is returned for the ChannelListEntry object.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.Clock
member.summary: The Clock class provides an interface for controlling the clock of a subsystem.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.Clock.Frequency
member.summary: Gets and sets the frequency of the internal clock source.
member.remarks: The driver sets the frequency of the internal clock as close as possible to the value that you specified in the Frequency property. You can determine the actual frequency that was set on the hardware by reading the value of the Frequency property after the subsystem has been configured (using the method).

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.Clock.Source
member.summary: Gets and sets the current clock source (Internal or External).

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.Clock.ExtClockDivider
member.summary: Gets and sets the current value of the external clock divider.
member.remarks: The external clock divider is used to determine the frequency of the external clock source. The frequency of the external clock input divided by the external clock divider determines the frequency of at which to pace the operation.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.Clock.SupportsInternalClock
member.summary: Returns True if the subsystem supports an internal clock source; otherwise, returns False.
member.remarks: Specify the clock source using the property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.Clock.SupportsExternalClock
member.summary: Returns True if the subsystem supports an external clock source; otherwise, returns False.
member.remarks: Specify the clock source using the property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.Clock.MinFrequency
member.summary: Returns the minimum allowable internal clock frequency supported by the subsystem.
member.remarks: Set the frequency of the internal clock using the property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.Clock.MaxFrequency
member.summary: Returns the maximum allowable internal clock frequency supported by the subsystem.
member.remarks: Set the frequency of the internal clock using the property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.Clock.MinExtClockDivider
member.summary: Returns the minimum allowable external clock divider value supported by the subsystem.
member.remarks: Set the external clock divider using the property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.Clock.MaxExtClockDivider
member.summary: Returns the maximum allowable external clock divider value supported by the subsystem.
member.remarks: Set the external clock divider using the property.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.Clock.BaseClockFrequency
member.summary: Returns the frequency of the base clock for the subsystem.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.Clock.SupportsSimultaneousClocking
member.summary: Returns True if the subsystem supports simultaneous clocking.
member.remarks: Some subsystems allow you to read or update multiple channels on a single clock pulse. This property allows you to determine whether multiple channels can be read or updated on a single clock pulse.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.DeviceMgr
member.summary: The DeviceMgr is a singleton class that is responsible for managing Open Layers devices in the system and for assigning objects.

member.name: M:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.DeviceMgr.Get
member.summary: Returns a DeviceMgr object.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ReferenceTrigger
member.summary: The ReferenceTrigger class provides an interface for controlling the reference trigger of a subsystem. For devices that support a reference trigger, pre-trigger data acquisition stops and post-trigger acquisition starts when the reference trigger event occurs. Post-trigger acquisition stops when the number of samples you specify for the post-trigger scan count has been reached.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ReferenceTrigger.TriggerType
member.summary: Gets and sets the reference trigger type (None, TTLPos, TTLNeg, DigitalEvent, ThresholdPos, or ThresholdNeg) for the subsystem.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.DeviceCollection.ReferenceTrigger.Level
member.summary: Gets and sets the threshold value for the reference trigger. By default, the threshold value is in voltage unless specified otherwise for the device; see the user's manual for your device for valid threshold value settings for the reference trigger.
member.remarks: This propery is valid only if TriggerType property is or trigger type. The threshold level set by this property is the value after the gain is a applied to the threshold trigger channel. For example, if the voltage range of the subsystem is Â±10 V, and the specified gain is 1, specify a threshold voltage level within Â±10 V. Likewise, if the voltage range of the subsystem is Â±10 V, and the specified gain is 10, specify a threshold voltage level within Â±1 V.

member.remarks: This propery is valid only if the property is ThresholdPos or ThresholdNeg.

member.summary: Returns the number of available subsystem elements for a given subsystem type.
member.param: The type of subsystem.
member.returns: The number of elements for the specified subsystem type.
member.remarks: Your device may support multiple instances, or elements, of the same subsystem type. Element numbering is zero-based; that is, the first instance of the subsystem is called element 0, the second instance of the subsystem is called element 1, and so on. For example, if your device has two digital input ports, two subsystems of type DigitalInput are available, differentiated as elements 0 and 1.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DtDevice.DTOverlapped.OVERLAPPED.offset
member.summary: Specifies a file position at which to start the transfer. The file position is a byte offset from the start of the file. The calling process sets this member before calling the ReadFile or WriteFile function. This member is ignored when reading from or writing to named pipes and communications devices and should be zero.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DtDevice.DTOverlapped.OVERLAPPED.offsetHigh
member.summary: Specifies the high word of the byte offset at which to start the transfer. This member is ignored when reading from or writing to named pipes and communications devices and should be zero.

member.name: F:OpenLayers.DtDevice.DTOverlapped.OVERLAPPED.hEvent
member.summary: Handle to an event set to the signaled state when the operation has been completed. The calling process must set this member either to zero or a valid event handle before calling any overlapped functions. To create an event object, use the CreateEvent function. Functions such as WriteFile set the event to the nonsignaled state before they begin an I/O operation.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.InterruptOnChangeHandler
member.summary: The InterruptOnChangeHandler delegate is called when the event InterruptOnChangeEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the event InterruptOnChangeEvent.
member.remarks: The event InterruptOnChangeEvent is raised by some devices when a digital input line changes state.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.BufferDoneHandler
member.summary: The BufferDoneHandler delegate is called when the event BufferDoneEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the event BufferDoneEvent.
member.remarks: For input operations, the event BufferDoneEvent is raised when the internal buffer of an object has been filled with post-trigger data. For output operations, this event is raised when all the data in the internal buffer of the OlBuffer object has been output.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.BufferReusedHandler
member.summary: The BufferReusedHandler delegate is called when the event BufferReusedEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the event BufferReusedEvent.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.DriverRunTimeErrorEventHandler
member.summary: The DriverRunTimeErrorEventHandler delegate is called when the DriverRunTimeErrorEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the DriverRunTimeErrorEvent.
member.remarks:
The DriverRunTimeErrorEvent occurs when the device driver detects one of the following error conditions during runtime:
FifoOverflow - The driver could not read data from the device FIFO (or Windows USB FIFO) fast enough, resulting in a FIFO overflow condition. To deal with this error, increase the buffer sizes, slow down the sampling rate, or stop other CPU-intensive running programs.
FifoUnderflow - The driver could not write data to the device FIFO (or Windows USB FIFO) fast enough, resulting in FIFO underflow condition. To deal with this error, increase the buffer sizes, slow down the sampling rate, or stop other CPU-intensive running programs.
DeviceOverClocked - The A/D clock (usually external clock) is running too fast on the device. To deal with this error, slow down the A/D clock.
TriggerError - The driver detected a trigger on the device but did not act on it.
DeviceError - Generated by the driver due to a USB bus or hardware problem. To deal with this error, stop connecting/disconnecting USB devices while streaming data to them.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.QueueDoneHandler
member.summary: The QueueDoneHandler delegate is called when the event QueueDoneEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the event QueueDoneEvent.
member.remarks: The event QueueDoneEvent is raised when no objects are available on the queue and the operation stops.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.QueueStoppedHandler
member.summary: The QueueStoppedHandler delegate is called when the event QueueStoppedEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the event QueueStoppedEvent.
member.remarks: A QueueStoppedEvent is raised when Stop or Abort is called for a continuous analog I/O operation. The event BufferDoneEvent is generated for the current buffer and for up to eight inprocess buffers before a QueueStoppedEvent event occurs.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.PreTriggerBufferDoneHandler
member.summary: The PreTriggerBufferDoneHandler delegate is called when the event PreTriggerBufferDoneEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the event PreTriggerBufferDoneEvent.
member.remarks: The event PreTriggerBufferDone is raised when the internal buffer of an object is filled with pre-trigger data (for an input operation only).

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.IOCompleteHandler
member.summary: The IOCompleteHandler delegate is called when the event IOCompleteEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the event IOCompleteEvent.
member.remarks:
For analog input operations that use a reference trigger whose trigger type is something other than software (none), the event IOCompleteEvent is raised when the last post-trigger sample is copied into the user buffer. Devices that do not support a reference trigger will never receive this event for analog input operations.
For analog output operations, the event IOCompleteEvent is raised when the last data point has been output from an analog output channel; in some cases, this event is raised well after the data is transferred from the buffer (and, therefore, well after the events BufferDoneEvent and QueueDoneEvents are raised).

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.GeneralFailureHandler
member.summary: The GeneralFailureHandler delegate is called when the event GeneralFailureEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the event GeneralFailureEvent.
member.remarks: The event GeneralFailureEvent is raised when a general library failure occurs.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.DeviceRemovedHandler
member.summary: The DeviceRemovedHandler delegate is called when the event DeviceRemovedEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the event DeviceRemovedEvent.
member.remarks: The event DeviceRemovedEvent is raised when a device is removed from your system while your application is running.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.EventDoneHandler
member.summary: The EventDoneHandler delegate is called when the event EventDoneEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the event EventDoneEvent.
member.remarks: The event EventDoneEvent is raised by some devices, such as the DT340, when a digital input line changes state or when an interval timer operation is complete

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.MeasureDoneHandler
member.summary: The MeasureDoneHandler delegate is called when the event MeasureDoneEvent occurs.
member.param: The subsystem that raised the event.
The object that is associated with the event MeasureDoneEvent.
member.remarks: The event MeasureDoneEvent is raised when a operation is complete.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.EventMgr
member.summary: The EventMgr class encapsulates the management of events initiated from the device driver or copy thread.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.BufferDoneEventArgs
member.summary: A BufferDoneEventArgs object is passed to one of the following delegates when the associated event occurs: delegate when the event BufferDoneEvent occurs or delegate when the event PreTriggerBufferDoneEvent occurs. BufferDoneEventArgs contains the data that is associated with the event, including the subsystem that raised the event, the time stamp of when the event occurred, and the completed object.
member.remarks:
For input operations, the event BufferDoneEvent is raised when the internal buffer of an object has been filled with post-trigger data. For output operations, this event is raised when all the data in the internal buffer of an object has been output.
If you stop an analog I/O operation, the event BufferDoneEvent is generated for the current OlBuffer object and for up to eight inprocess OlBuffer objects before a QueueStoppedEvent event occurs.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.GeneralEventArgs
member.summary: GeneralEventArgs is the base class for all event data. GeneralEventArgs contains the data that is passed to all events, including the subsystem that raised the event, and the time stamp of when the event occurred.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.GeneralEventArgs.DateTime
member.summary: Returns the time stamp of when the associated event occurred.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.GeneralEventArgs.Subsystem
member.summary: Returns the subsystem that raised the event.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.BufferDoneEventArgs.OlBuffer
member.summary: Returns the completed object.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.IOCompleteEventArgs
member.summary: An IOCompleteEventArgs object is passed to the delegate when the event IOCompleteEvent occurs. IOCompleteEventArgs contains the data associated with the event IOCompleteEvent. For analog input operations, this includes the total number of samples per channel that were acquired from the time acquisition was started to the last post-trigger sample, and the subsystem that raised the event. For analog output operations, this is the subsystem that raised the event.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.IOCompleteEventArgs.LastSampleNumber
member.summary: (For analog input operations only) returns the total number of samples per channel that were acquired from the time acquisition was started (with the start trigger) to the last post-trigger sample.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.EventDoneEventArgs
member.summary: An EventDoneEventArgs object is passed to the delegate when the event EventDoneEvent occurs. EventDoneEventArgs contains the data that is associated with the event EventDoneEvent, including the subsystem that raised the event and the time stamp of when the event occurred.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.EventDoneEventArgs.Data
member.summary: Returns the data that is associated with the event EventDoneEvent. The meaning of this data depends on your device and the subsystem used. Refer to your device documentation for more information.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.InterruptOnChangeEventArgs
member.summary: An InterruptOnChangeEventArgs object is passed to the delegate when the event InterruptOnChangeEvent occurs. InterruptOnChangeEventArgs contains the data that is associated with the event InterruptOnChangeEvent, including the subsystem that raised the event, the time stamp of when the event occurred, the digital input lines that changed state, and the current state of the digital input port.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.InterruptOnChangeEventArgs.NewValue
member.summary: Returns the current value of the digital input port.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.InterruptOnChangeEventArgs.ChangedBits
member.summary: Returns the digital input lines that changed state, causing the event InterruptOnChangeEvent to occur.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.MeasureDoneEventArgs
member.summary: A MeasureDoneEventArgs object is passed to the delegate when the event MeasureDoneEvent occurs. MeasureDoneEventArgs contains the data that is associated with the event MeasureDoneEvent, including the subsystem that raised the event, the time stamp of when the event occurred, and the count.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.MeasureDoneEventArgs.Count
member.summary: Returns the number of internal clock pulses that were counted during the measure period.

member.name: T:OpenLayers.Base.DriverRunTimeErrorEventArgs
member.summary: A DriverRunTimeErrorEventArgs object is passed to the delegate when when the event DriverRunTimeErrorEvent occurs. DriverRunTimeErrorEventArgs contains the error/warning that is generated by the device driver, an error message that describes the error/warning, the subsystem that raised the event, and the time stamp of when the event occurred.
member.remarks:
The DriverRunTimeErrorEvent occurs when the device driver detects one of the following error conditions:
FifoOverflow - The driver could not read data from the device FIFO (or Windows USB FIFO) fast enough, resulting in a FIFO overflow condition. To deal with this error, increase the buffer sizes, slow down the sampling rate, or stop other CPU-intensive running programs.
FifoUnderflow - The driver could not write data to the device FIFO (or Windows USB FIFO) fast enough, resulting in FIFO underflow condition. To deal with this error, increase the buffer sizes, slow down the sampling rate, or stop other CPU-intensive running programs.
DeviceOverClocked - The A/D clock (usually external clock) is running too fast on the device. To deal with this error, slow down the A/D clock.
TriggerError - The driver detected a trigger on the device but did not act on it.
DeviceError - Generated by the driver due to a USB bus or hardware problem. To deal with this error, stop connecting/disconnecting USB devices while streaming data to them.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.DriverRunTimeErrorEventArgs.ErrorCode
member.summary: Returns the from the Open Layers for .NET Class Library that is associated with the driver error.

member.name: P:OpenLayers.Base.DriverRunTimeErrorEventArgs.Message
member.summary: Returns the descriptive string for the driver error.
